Brantford, Ont., July 10th 1940.

Dr. W. Davis,

Dear Doctor Davis:

Re: x-ray film No. 3405,

Harry Commendant.

The trachea is central. The heart is normal in size, shape and position. The domes of the diaphragm are smooth and rounded. The costo-phrenic angles are clear.

Right lung: Some fine infiltration and stranding is present in the first and second interspaces. The hilus shadows are heavy and the lung markings are prominent.

Left lung: Some fine infiltration is seen in the outer portion of the first and second interspaces. Hilus shadows and lung markings are prominent.

Conclusion: The infiltration seen in the upper portion of both lung fields may represent pulmonary tuberculosis although it does not appear to be very active. I would suggest that this boy return for a repeat x-ray in one month.

CRM/W.

Yours very truly,

C.R. Messer, M.D.

August 17, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith applications for admission to the Mount Elgin School of two children of Napoleon Commandant of the Gibson Band. These applications have been signed by the children's mother and I have not taken the trouble to have the father sign them as I cannot take my way to recommend that they be admitted to the school. One of the boys is already fifteen years old and he can quite readily, as can the other, complete his education in Bala where the parents have been living for a number of years. They have not for some time resided on the Gibson Reserve.

Yours truly,

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

Trusota - Mt. Kitch Indian Residential School, Nancy (Niagara Falls Detachment Investigation)

With reference to Cat. No. 10618 connection with the above named subject.

Whilst other police actions in the district on the Lake District, no clues were found, but no information could be obtained in regard to the whereabouts of Sheila and Helen SCHILLER, Indian girls who are believed to be in this district.

Further inquiries were made with constables throughout the district, who have been employed by the Canadian Canoe Co., St. David, Ontario, but no information regarding the above mentioned girls or their whereabouts could be obtained.

[Signature]

To - The O/O "O" Division.

1. NOMINATED 23-8-40.

2. The celebration referred to in Constable Headlam's report is, as is known, an annual event and Indians are given free access across the border which makes it impossible to ascertain whether the above named girls were among them.

3. A thorough check of the district has been made with negative results but as the fruit is just starting to come in it is more than likely that the girls may be in that type of work they will soon work, and with this in mind "lockouts" have been placed throughout the district.

4. If located the girls will be returned to the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School and report submitted.

[Signature]

1/o Niagara Falls Detachment.

Reverend O. B. Strapp, Principal of the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, has written the Schools Branch about Patricia Hill stating that she has venereal disease and for that reason cannot be kept in the School.

We should be glad to have a report from you on this matter.

Christian Island, Ontario
September 19th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I would beg to refer you to my two letters of July 6th, 1940 in connection with admittance of children of the Christian Island Agency to residential school.

In my one letter of July 16th I gave details concerning two children belonging to No. 215, and wrote that in the other letter of even date I submitted details in connection with the children belonging to No. 237 (now No. 238) of the Christian Island Band. To date, no reply has been received as to Departmental approval or otherwise and as the parents do not care to know whether their children will be admitted or not, it will be appreciated if early attention can be given to the matter.

I shall also have to also meet the question of a child who (I believe) was at this school last year. This child, last year's child, is now five years old and is about to start school next fall. Whether she will attend this school or not depends entirely upon the wishes of her parents. She is now five years old and has never been away from home except for a short time when she was very young and has not been there ever since.

Another was recently taken into the band with the approval of the Dr. who said she is known as a member of the tribe but her parents have left, of course, no letter of address.

Concerning the case of this child, I am willing to take her elsewhere at any other school if necessary. The child is now attending school here but the parents want her to go back to her own band. If she is allowed to go back she will be going for her. I have not been able to find out what she was doing while I was little more than at the present time. A woman named Jacob King has made some inquiries to Rev. Strapp to have the girl admitted and therefore considered that I should bring the matter to the attention of the Department.

Secretary,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken,
In Charge
Christian Island Agency.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

September 24, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant the Department wrote to the Principal of the Moome Algin school on July 12 regarding the admission of the five children from the Christian Island Agency. As yet he has not advised us if he can provide accommodation for them. I am consequently writing to him again today requesting an immediate reply and as soon as he does so you will be advised.

In view of the information contained in your letter the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of Henrietta King to any Indian residential school at the present time.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

CANADA
With reference to the above named girl, whom Reverend O.B. Strapp, Principal of the school has reported as afflicted with venereal disease, I have to report that he has discussed this case with me several times. This pupil is about seven years old, is the daughter of Mr. Hill, of the First Nation, and her father is believed to be white.

She has been a ward of the Bishop's Missionary Order at St. Thomas, Ontario, for some time, and is known to have congenital Syphilis. Her mother has been under treatment at this office for the same disease, and Patricia has received some treatments from Dr. Fry, of St. Thomas, who examined her on admission to the school.

The suggestion that Patricia be isolated in the school for a short time, or kept in an Indian home while she is undergoing treatment is not practical, as expert opinion, with which I agree, is that at her age, she could be treated for years intravenously, and still yield a positive blood test.

Principal Strapp is quite definite in his stand that he does not wish any girl to be in his school with venereal disease, congenital or otherwise. He says that the attitude of his pupils, as they are composed of other pupils, all of which have been treated, makes that this case may be handled rather than by nature. He stated that I thought this girl would be very improved after treatment. Said I would, and that I felt there would be no harm in allowing her to attend the school, provided she was treated in the manner described.

I am, Sir,

[Signature]

Medical Superintendent

Paradise Agency

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

30-9-40.

In This Detachment was advised by Ind. Peter WILLIAMS, Service Unit, Barrie, that two young Indians had been seen near the school grounds and that they were suspected to have stolen some property. The child whose name is mentioned above was reported missing from the school grounds.

Sub-Division

Detachment

P.C.R.

The writer contacted Cst. Redman, I/C Munro Detachment, by telephone and informed him that two young Indians were seen near the school grounds. He was instructed to report this information to the detachment at once.

Further inquiries were made this date by members of this detachment and it was learned that the two Indians were still missing but had been seen near the school grounds. They were reported to have left the area recently and no trace of them has been found since.

The writer patrolled per Pol. Car, Code No. 265, to Munro this date with the two above named Indians and turned them over to the Principal at the local school. A report will be submitted.

Expenses - See P. 98 for period Oct. 1/15.

Dear Dr. McLeod:

Re: Marita Nicholas, Muncey

The above noted girl was re-examined at the Victoria Hospital Chest Clinic on September 26th, 1940, previous to admission to Residential School. She has had no recent illness and has been feeling quite well.

Physical Examination - Temperature 98.3, pulse 84, respirations 20, weight 117 lbs. She is well developed and well nourished. Nothing abnormal found on examination of the chest.

X-Ray of chest - there is no change since the previous examination.

We are unable to detect any tuberculous disease in this girl's chest at this examination.

We trust this report will be satisfactory to you.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

1. This Detachment was advised this date by Indian Cst. Peter Williams, Sarnia Indian Reserve that the above two girls had been seen on the Reserve in the early P.M. and requested the assistance of this Force in locating them.

2. The writer patrolled per Police Car Code No. 2669 to the Sarnia Indian Reserve and in company with Indian Cst. Williams located Emma GRAY at the home of her grandmother. On being questioned she stated that she was a truant from the Mount Elgin Institute, Munsey, Ont. and that she had left there on the night of Sept. 29-30th.

3. The patrol was continued in an effort to locate Gloria Fisher but numerous inquiries failed to reveal her whereabouts.

4. Emma GRAY was brought to Sarnia and was taken to the Children's Aid Society for keeping over night. Inquiries were continued in effort to locate Gloria Fisher.

5. The writer patrolled this date per Police Car Code No. 2669 to the Sarnia Indian Reserve and after some inquiries Gloria FISHER was finally located at her mother's home. When questioned she stated that she was a truant and had left the Mount Elgin Institute on the night of Sept. 29-30th.

6. The writer patrolled to Munsey with the above two girls and turned them over to the Principal of the Mount Elgin Institute.

Christian Island, Ontario
October 17th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-10 of October 3rd authorizing me to send five children from the Christian Island Agency to Mount Elgin Indian Residential School.

Immediately upon receiving the authorization, I advised the parents of these children that their admittance to residential school in the near future was desired. They claimed that they could not pay the transportation but later agreed to pay expenses out of interest money due them this fall.

When making arrangements regarding the sending of these children to the Mt. Elgin School I found out that Leslie McCue and Nora Monague both have a serious skin disease and at the present time it would not be wise to send them as they would not be admitted to the School. It will be impossible to send them until this disease has been cured, they are both being given treatment for the disease at the present time and will, in all probability, be free of it in about two weeks. As soon as the disease clears up, I shall arrange to send them to the school and the parents will pay all expenses. I trust that this will meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

No contact with tuberculosis established.

We were unable to obtain any history.

There was no direct contact.

The patient was examined - tuberculin skin test and examination of the chest.

Intracutaneous tuberculin test, no reaction of 1/1000, normal.

There is no evidence of tuberculosis, and there has been no exposure to tuberculosis.

We have not been able to find any evidence of active pulmonary tuberculosis.

To date, there is no evidence of any form of tuberculosis.

A final tuberculin report will be sent to you shortly.

I would be pleased to acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-10 of December 3rd with reference to five children of the Christian Island Band who were to be admitted to the Mount Sinai Indian Residential School.

The parents of these children were told that they would be expected to pay for transportation. They hesitatingly agreed to do this as soon as they received their allotment money or whatever last but one payment was made.

In November, one of the parents objected to paying a reasonable fare and said that she would make other arrangements to get her children there but this was, as usual, only an excuse and nothing was done on her part.

There has been one delay after another in connection with sending these children to residential school. The parents have not been interested in the matter now. The children are attending day school on the reserve and are being fairly well looked after by the Agency. Snow blocked roads now present a little trouble regarding their travel.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The enclosed applications for admission to Muncey Indian Residential School are from non-Band members of Stony Point Reserve.

The mother of Eunice and Eleanor died about two years ago. Ida is the illegitimate daughter of an older daughter of Simpson George. Since Mrs. George died the children have been very much neglected until today the white population are complaining of the children being left alone and crying along the roadside. Sometimes without food. The father has been warned several times and assistance has been given. It now appears that some action is needed to be taken against him.

Should there be any vacancies, I would recommend that these children be admitted as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Geo. W. Down,

On this date I was advised by officials of the above mentioned school, that the following Indian boys ran away from school immediately after breakfast on this date. Assistance was requested in locating them and returning them to school.

Sub-Division

Clarence CHARLES - Oseida Indian Reserve.
Finley AYTON - Oseida Indian Reserve.
Ivan HENRY - Brantford, Ontario.

Detachment

Accompanied by S/Cpl. Johnson, I immediately commenced a patrol of the reserve, where information was obtained that these boys had been seen on the banks of the Thames River, and were believed to be heading for Road Highway at Delaware, Ontario.

F.C.R.

A careful search was made of the river bank for a distance of approximately 10 miles from the school, since these boys were seen walking along the bank, two of these boys were caught namely: Finley AYTON and Ivan HENRY, the third boy Clarence CHARLES, making a getaway in a thick bush. The boys were handed over to Rev. O.S. Strapp, Principal of the above school, and a search was continued for CHARLES. He was later caught in a thick bush near his home on the Oseida Reserve. He was escorted back to school, and handed over to Rev. O.S. Strapp.

N.E.I.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

On receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo your recommendation regarding keeping certain pupils in the Mount Elgin Residential School for another year was carefully discussed with Mr. Hoey. Under present conditions, and on account of the many demands which we receive from deserving pupils for accommodation in residential schools, we feel that it would be a mistake to keep the pupils you mention for a further year in the Mount Elgin Residential School. Under these circumstances it has been decided that pupils numbered as follows should be considered discharged:

No. 0709 No. 0809 No. 7317 No. 0724
" 0776 " 0850 " 735 " 0753
" 0779 " 704 " 744 " 0766
" 0807 " 719 " 0700 " 0827

I have discussed this matter with Miss Moodie and she seems to be under the impression that there might be a few of the girls who would profit by a year's special training in domestic science. Miss Moodie intends to write to you in regard to this matter and in the event of your deciding that a few of them would profit by the additional domestic science training we will be prepared to favourably consider their re-admission to the school for the academic year 1941-42.

Dear Sir:

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-0-10 of August 27th in connection with Wilbert Brown, a pupil of the Mount Elgin School, whose mother wishes to have discharged owing to ill health.

Rev. Strapp, Principal of the School, stated to me that this boy should be requested to remain at the School unless proof is furnished that his health would suffer if such action were taken. As far as can be ascertained this boy did not require any medical attention during his previous term at the School and he appeared to be in good health.

It appears as if the mother of this boy is unwilling for him to go back to the school for some reason, probably due to the fact that he can work now and would be earning money which he would no doubt turn over to his mother. The R.C.M. Police had to visit the Brown home last year to get the boy to return to Mount Elgin and at that time the mother caused considerable disturbance.

I would suggest that this boy be re-examined by our Medical Superintendent and if Dr. Jamieson finds him in good health he should be forced to return to the School. This cannot be done until the boy returns to the Reserve as he is now working in some white municipality with his parents. When Wilbert was admitted to the School on September 17th, 1938, he was ten years of age and in my opinion he should return to the School, health permitting.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken,

Dear Dr. Jamieson:

Re: Martha Dolson, Children's Aid Society, St. Thomas,

August 27th, 1941

The above noted patient was examined at chest clinic held at Victoria Hospital on August 21st, 1941.

There is no history of contact with tuberculosis. This is a routine examination preparatory to entrance to Indian Residential School.

This child gives no complaints or symptoms referable to the chest.

Past Illnesses: Pertussis at aged ten - no complications; measles at eleven - eyes affected afterwards. Tonsillitis on several occasions; recurrent cervical adenitis; frequent chest colds which are difficult to clear up.

Family History: Father unknown. Mother living and well; four sisters living and well, one sister died - cause unknown. Five brothers living and well.

Physical examination reveals a moderately well nourished young female Indian child, aged 11, showing good nutrition and a fair color.

Examination of the chest reveals good expansion. Breath sounds are clear. A few moist rales are heard at the right base posteriorly where there is some impairment of resonance.

X-ray examination shows no evidence of any active pulmonary tuberculosis or bronchiectasis.

Opinion: This is a normal chest.

We trust this report is satisfactory and thank you for referring this patient to us.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

I have your letter of March 5, with account in connection with the weaving class.

With reference to your suggestion that looms should be supplied to the girls of this class, I am not convinced that this is a good thing to do, but as we cannot be certain the girls will be able to use the looms until we give them the opportunity, I think we are justified in making the experiment when the class is made up of only six girls. This authorizes the expenditure of $80 for the purchase of lumber, and my understanding is that you are willing to arrange to have the boys in the manual training shop make the looms without cost to the Department. If you will let me have the necessary information as to the size and measurement of steel combs required, we will order them from the Montreal Steel Heddle Company and have them sent to you at Muncey. In submitting your account please state on the voucher that payment is to be made from "Schools Vote" and refer to this letter as authority for expenditure for the lumber.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

With reference to your letter of the 27th instant I have discussed your request for the two sewing machines with our Purchasing Branch. It appears that the type you request are electric machines and, while I would like to supply them, I regret that present regulations prevent our doing so. The argument used is that electric machines do not provide the training for the children that they require in view of the fact that few, if any, of them will have electric machines when they return to their homes. I can very easily secure either the regular type machine or, if you wish it, the so-called tailor machine which, as you know, is a heavier stronger machine than the ordinary one. I should appreciate your considering the matter again and advising me.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

May 10th, 1946.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Mount Elgin Residential School

Some time ago Mr. Strapp of Brandon wrote, asking what was to be done with certain equipment at Mount Elgin, which is the property of the Department. In my letter to him I pointed that out, and as a result Mr. Strapp has written to Mr. Phelan, who has replied to say that there is no objection on the part of the French to the transfer of the Manual Training equipment from the Mount Elgin School to Brandon; and Mr. Strapp has written to Mr. Soper, suggesting that he come down and crate the material.

I have not much time today to go into the matter in any detail, but I feel that I must write immediately to ask whether consideration has been given to the fact that some of the equipment - how much I cannot tell - should be left at Mount Elgin, so that it could be used in the development of the courses which it is proposed to have initiated in connection with the new school. I have no list of what is at Mount Elgin, and it may be that none of the materials there will be useful in the new set-up; but it does seem to me as if, in view of the fact that the school is not to be closed until June 30th, there has been a little haste in assuring Mr. Strapp that he can get all this material.

I have not a copy of the letter which Mr. Strapp has written to your Department, and consequently I do not know what he proposed to take away. We have, of course, no objection to the Brandon School getting some of the equipment, but we must, at the same time, protect the interests of the new set-up at Mount Elgin.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, May 14, 1946.

Dear Mr. Strapp:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 2nd instant and my reply of the 6th instant, with reference to transferring some of the manual training equipment from the Mount Elgin Residential School to the Brandon Residential School.

It is our intention to erect a new day school on the Caradoc Reserve and vocational training will be taught. Consequently, there will be necessity for some of the equipment in the new school, and in that event there would not be any advantage in transferring it to Brandon, because we would have to purchase new equipment for the Caradoc School.

I intend to visit Mount Elgin next week, at which time I will look over the equipment, and I will write to you on my return. In the meantime, no further action should be taken towards transferring this equipment.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir;

I have just received your letter of the 15th instant, and I am glad to hear that the school has been closed at your request. I have been in touch with Mr. Strapp regarding the transfer of the school furniture equipment at the school to this school. He informed me that he thought there would be no objection to the transfer of such equipment that was not the property of the United Church.

A high speed drill press was purchased directly by Indian Affairs, and the metal working tools were transferred from the Christie Street Hospital, Toronto. The high speed saw and jointer combination unit was purchased through sale of beaten metal work done by the boys. The wood working benches and tools were supplied by Indian Affairs.

I believe that it was a good idea to transfer these items. If they had not transferred we would not have had the freedom of time.

Last year a proposal was made that Indians in the west be willing to pay a portion toward the salary of a manual arts teacher for this school, but the idea unfortunately has not taken root, and nothing happened. I am wondering whether something can be done for the opening of school in September of this year.

In correspondence with Mr. Candy who was the senior teacher here a couple of years ago and left to enlist in the forces. He is interested in Manual Arts and Physical Training, and on his release...
from the forces would like to return to our staff.

I shall be glad to have your decision on this proposal at your earliest convenience.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Joblin:

I am holding up your requisition for material for vocational work because I am unaware of which course you are following. The General Shop Course of Ontario reads in part as follows:

"Drafting is obligatory and any three of the following may be selected: applied electricity, farm mechanics, forge and vice work, machine shop practice, ornamental metal work, motor mechanics, sheet metal work, woodwork."

Which three subjects are you selecting for the boys?

Kindly let me have this information at your earliest convenience after which attention to the requisition may be given.

Dear Mr. Doucet,

In reply to your letter of June 20th, I have been in consultation with Mr. Johnston with regard to the subjects to be taken in General Shop. We have agreed that for the present at least we should make our choices from Section II-III-IV-VI.

For this section, we have selected the following subsections, which will give us a good range of work:

- Woodwork,
- Metal work,
- Farm Mechanics.

Since I have been accepted for the course at Toronto, it is possible that I may see you there before I have had an opportunity of acting on this reply. This may not be so, however, unless we have not quite satisfied these points.

Gentlemen:

The Canada Metal Company of Montreal have passed on to us our recent quotation request, covering one sheet of pewter about 70 lbs.

We must advise that we are not in a position to give you your quotation on Pewter Metal, owing to the fact that we have not manufactured this material for some years now.

It is our understanding that the manufacture of Pewter Metal is prohibited owing to the fact that there is a high percentage of pure Tin in the finished material. Pure Tin is at the present time under control of the Administrator of Non-Ferrous Metals in Ottawa, and the Metals Controller has not been fit to release Tin for use in manufacturing either Pewter Metal or Britannia Metal.

We thank you most sincerely for the opportunity of quoting you, and sincerely regret that we are not able to take care of your requirements.

Yours very truly,

Re: Kitchen Unit for Mt. Elgin Indian Day School
Departmental File 468-11 (E 1)

As requested in your letter of November 4th we enclose, herewith, a sketch showing the proposed unit.

Before a definite decision is made on this matter, however, I should like to bring to your attention a few facts and suggestions bearing on the case.

It has been pointed out that if the basement rooms of the Mt. Elgin Day School are used for Manual Training and Home Economics classes, then the school will be without a suitable playroom or gymnasium. Furthermore, it will be a comparatively easy task to put the Manual Training material and equipment out of harm's way when not in use. It will be a somewhat more difficult task to protect a considerable amount of classroom furniture, etc., in a room which is of necessity used as a thoroughfare between the classroom and the toilet. It has been suggested that to solve the problem we might build a Home Economics cottage wherein all the Home Economics equipment may be housed and wherein all the classes could be held in a setting more closely resembling the homes of the pupils. It would thus provide protection for the equipment, a better classroom and would release the basement room for use as an auditorium, playroom and gymnasium.

I have taken the trouble to have estimated the cost of material for a cottage 24' square, set on a concrete base, insulated, gyproc lined, covered with Johns-Manville Asbestos shingles and wired for electricity — approximately $1150.00.

To construct such a cottage would ordinarily double the cost but by allowing the senior boys to do a large portion of the work under proper supervision, we could provide them with valuable experience, and we estimate that it would reduce the cost of construction to $500.00 which would place the total cost of the completed cottage at between $1600.00 and $1700.00.

It may be that the Department might consider the suggestion of such a cottage. If so, they wish to hold up the construction of the kitchen unit until we have it built in such a way that it could be fitted into the cottage.

All of which we respectfully submit for your consideration.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall,

Muncey, Ontario,
January 18th 1934.

Dear Doctor Stone;

Information regarding conditions at Mount Elgin Residential School, as you are no doubt aware, was recently requested from Mr. Moore, by the Secretary, and as Director of Medical Services I believe you should have further data from me. On the whole, the inferences drawn from outside sources looks fairly serious on paper, but generally speaking the medical department and health of the pupils is in good shape.

Regarding the skin condition introduced into the picture I may say that on taking over this appointment Dr. Fardy informed me that there was an obstinate condition at this Agency which he could not name or cure. It is a cross between secondarily infected Impetigo and a Pemphigus, and is sporadic in its appearance. Several times it has been identified only to disappear after the children return from visits to their respective homes. It is present both on the reserves and at the school, and seems to run in families, Wassermann tests proving negative. At no time was there any great number of children affected, but it is a nasty looking disorder and leaves scars. Ammoniated Mercury Ointment proved useless in treating it and I obtained the best results from Bichloride Washes and internal use of Cod Liver Oil, and the latter suggests a lack of vitamin A partial etiology. At present it is cleaned up, and there is not a case at Mount Elgin Institute. I talked to Dr. Wall about it, and may have mentioned it to you previously. At any rate I was always aware of the situation and we have done our best to cope with the situation, now well in hand. While its degree of infectivity is low, we had separate towels for all patients, and I have been successful in obtaining separate towels for all pupils at Mount Elgin. This skin infection was usually absent on the face but seemed to have an affinity for hands and buttocks, and we had the toilets washed with a solution of Lysol after affected ones utilized them. I am pleased to report that everyone at the Institute co-operated to the fullest in cleaning up this disease which did not involve more than a dozen pupils over a period of 2 years and three of them were from one family.

...........
With reference to food provided pupils at Mount Elgin Institute I have inspected the tables ready for serving several times and concluded that a well balanced ration was provided. I believe that you remarked upon the same thing during your visit to Muncy. Further I have on file a letter from Rev. S.R. McVitty Principal, dated May 15th 1932, in which he says in part; "An abundance of excellent food such as whole milk (50% Jersey), butter, eggs, meat, bread, and a superabundance of fresh vegetables are served daily, and I am pleased to say that the wonderfully healthy appearance of our pupils calls forth the admiration of our many visitors. The usual comment is that white children have no such accommodation. This we know to be true." As for the egg ration I have taken the Reverend Gentleman's word for it, but agree that despite the absence of such food the children are in fine physical condition and have been prior to my appointment. I feel that any grievance regarding food is trivial and can be easily remedied.

Regarding bath accommodation for pupils this is in need of improvement, but until financial conditions warranted same, like many other of our needs the end justifies the means. Toilet accommodation is in a similar category, and Mr. McVitty informed me that indoor flush toilets for pupils was an endless source of trouble due to foreign material being thrown in them by ignorant pupils. The outside toilets are kept in a clean sanitary condition and I have inspected them several times.

Aside from the incident reported to you on December 12th, 1932, wherein the Principal refused to supply orange juice to a Pneumonia patient at Mount Elgin Institute after I had requested same there has been no friction.

I believe that a few recommendations are in order for the Institute worthy of consideration. They are as follows;

1. That all pupils submit to a blood Wassermann test for Syphilis. All new pupils from this Agency examined by me are so tested, but those in the school should have this done as a protection to themselves and others.

2. The system of ventilation in the sleeping dormitories be improved. At present this is notoriously poor particularly if there are many pupils ill. Mr. O.B. Strapp, assistant principal and myself have repeatedly discussed the situation and if limited funds were available an electric motor and large fan for each dormitory would make conditions satisfactory.

3. Installation of modern bath equipment when and as finances will permit.
Provision of modern flush toilets (to augment one in each dormitory now used at night), either indoors or out for the pupils with a campaign of education and supervision as to management by pupils.

5. A tooth brush for every pupil. Older pupils use them but in my opinion all should for the moral effect if no other goal is attained.

Insofar as the Medical end of the Department is concerned I believe that this covers the situation, and I'd being forwarded to you in the belief that this report will supplement that from the Indian Agent, the latter (from a layman's point of view), not covering the medical end of the problem as fully as might be desired.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

T. Roy McLeod, M.D.
Medical Superintendent,
Caradoc Agency.

Dr. E.L. Stone,
Director of Medical Services,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
January 25th, 1934.

Dear Doctor McLeod,

I have your letter of the 18th instant and it is regarded as a valuable contribution to the subjects discussed therein. I think only one or two parts require comments on my part.

I agree with you that all pupils entering school should have an examination for syphilis regardless of where they come from. This is a matter which you are competent to arrange but I am pleased to support your opinion. You appear to have the skin condition in hand and there is nothing I can add to your discussion of this particular matter.

I suppose there is no institution in the world with which fault cannot be found, and those in which young children are maintained are particularly open to attack. Knowing the very substantial improvement in our Residential schools in the last five or six years and the earnest endeavour the Department is making to keep up the standard under difficult financial conditions, I really regret to see them publically criticized. My impression from this particular controversy is that the author of it has some private spite against the church and the Department.

Yours truly,

T. Roy McLeod, Esq., M.D.,
Medical Superintendent,
Caradoc Agency,
LUNCY, Ont.

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services.

I am enclosing herewith a report on the inspection of Mount Elgin Residential School pupils and those of the day school pupils at this Agency conducted by Miss Murdoch and myself recently.

While there is an increase of seven cases of trachoma at Mount Elgin and seven more cases in the day school, along with several listed as suspicious, there is no cause for alarm as several of these are new pupils and the diagnosis is subject to confirmation.

In connection with my report which shows a general improvement in the health of the school children, I would recommend the following:

1. Services of a dentist for six days at Mount Elgin Residential School, and four days for pupils of the day school. If any further service is needed by current pupils, Dr. Ackland of Delaware engaged last year did excellent work, and this service was greatly appreciated by the Indians.

2. Permission for extraction of tonsils or other surgery on day school pupils as listed in Report attached hereto. If desired this work can be done during hospital periods during the next few weeks.

3. A visit by Dr. Wall as time permits to check up on treatment and diagnosis of Trachoma cases at this Agency. His visits are a great help to your local superintendent in his Trachoma work.

Yours very truly,

I am having sent to you a sample of a remedy called "Sphincterline" which is highly recommended by its makers and by one or two of our residential school principals for bed wetting. I should appreciate your trying this remedy a careful and thorough trial and letting me know as soon as possible whether you find it effective. I am well aware of the importance of this problem in most Indian residential schools and would be pleased to find some remedy which would help to solve it.

You have probably had some of the incontinence tablets which have been used for this purpose, and I would appreciate your opinion on the relative merits of the two preparations.

Yours truly,

H. L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services.

The Principal,
Mount Alpin Indian Residential School,
Moosey, Ontario.

Dear Doctor Stone,

I am enclosing herewith a report on the inspection of Mount Elgin Residential School pupils and those of the Day school pupils at this Agency, conducted by Miss Murdoch and myself.

While there is no increase in Trachoma at Mount Elgin definitely established, the increased number of suspects will likely bring up our total when confirmed by Dr. Wall. Of the new cases I have to report that some of them are new pupils who have brought the disease in with them from their respective reserves. I note that most of our defective children are senior pupils on the school roll, just why, I am not prepared to state.

Rev. O.B. Strapp is quite anxious that the impaired vision found among his pupils, (and which he has mentioned several times before inspection), be attended to, and I suspect that several of the girls at least have feigned impairment in the test, under the impression that glasses will improve their appearance, which is not original on their part.

In connection with my report I would recommend:

1. Services of a dentist for six days at Mount Elgin Residential School and for four days for the pupils of Day Schools or any portion thereof as funds permit. Dr. Askland of Mount Brydges has done excellent work in past years and is available this year.

2. Permission for extraction of tonile of eight day school and fifteen residential school pupils. This can be carried out periodically during slack hospital months if preferred.

3. Refraction and glasses if necessary for six day school pupils and fifteen residential school pupils at an estimate by Dr. Dobb if done in numbers at $6 per pupil including glasses.

4. A visit by Dr. J.J.Wall to check my diagnosis and treatment of Trachoma.

Yours very truly,

Muncey, Ontario.
October 28th, 1935.

Dear Doctor Stone;

I have to report that there is an outbreak of German Measles at Mount Elgin Residential School, and to date there have been 42 cases. The symptoms have been very mild being mainly cervical and occipital adenitis, sore throat, conjunctivitis, a slight fever, in no case exceeding 100 degrees, accompanied by rash of varying intensity. The first cases were put down to overeating of fruit on the part of the pupils, and it was only when the numbers increased that my attention was called to the afflicted, some of whom had not taken to bed or reported their illness to the staff.

The average duration of indisposition on the part of the children has been two days, and recovery has been exceptionally rapid. I detected one case on the Chippewa Reserve today, and the young daughter of the Mounted Police Constable here has just recovered from a similar attack. With the co-operation of the Institute staff I have instituted such quarantine measures as are feasible under the sudden onset of the outbreak. I feel that this epidemic will likely sweep through the school and reserves, but it is of such mild character that there is no cause for alarm.

I am informed that this disease has been prevalent, and undiagnosed in the vicinity of Shuben, eight miles from here. Several of those pupils who suffered severe attacks of typical measles last summer at the Residential School, including two who had the hemorrhagic type have been down and subsequently recovered from this latest illness.

Yours very truly,

T.Hey McLeod, M.D.

Dear Doctor Stone;

Referring to the recent flight letter sent by Mr. Moore, requesting permission to engage the services of an assistant nurse for Mount Eliza Residential School, I have to report that the situation has since greatly improved, and it may not be necessary to implement the authority granted.

As previously reported there have been upwards of fifty cases of German measles among the pupils, the epidemic being very widespread in form. This situation has been very nicely handled with no complications, and but one case reported on the reserves. To our chagrin, however, the pupils are being visited by a form of influenza (at least that is my diagnosis), and in most cases these children have escaped the measles. The onset of this illness is very abrupt with temperatures elevated as high as 105.2 and most of them in excess of 104 degrees. The initial symptom is headache, and pain in the chest. The latter is only caused being exceptionally severe, and in most cases in the right chest. In fact my first case showed pain in the right shoulder region with marked tenderness which presented a surgical problem, and several similar cases since have lead us to believe that this is due to irritation of the diaphragm in that area.

Physical signs at onset show no abnormality of the chest excepting harsh breath sounds, but in about 2-4 hours moist rales are present with a Bronch-Pneumonia. This is the picture in every one of six cases, and the routine of the disease is very interesting, and I may say new to me. All cases have done well under treatment although they have been very ill patients, and required much nursing care. Three patients are in the midst of the attack now, and the others are on the mend which seems to require about one week to get under way. One case, the first, was very severely ill, and as a result of isolation, and also for better treatment facilities I removed her to hospital 112.
ambulance. She is now recovering, and was a great interest to
the medical staff, there being three different clinics held
during her acute stage. Incidentally, the patient seems to
have a crisis, and for this reason, Lobar Pneumonia was
considered, but the course is too short and snappy in
addition to being wicked while it lasts.

I have been very interested and have seen every patient
daily, and feel that you would appreciate the details of this
rarity, which to date has not hit the reserves. The Measles
quarantine was enforced for this illness also, and may account
for a portion of our success in limiting the outbreak.

Reverting to the nursing problem, Miss Carlson, the
permanent nurse at the institution, in addition to her normal
duties as a girls' supervisor. These duties included checking
the pupils in the dormitory at night, and rousing them in the
morning. She has done excellent service in nursing the sick, and
I was under the impression that she would be relieved of her
supervisory duties, particularly in view of the fact that she
has been up to see the patients several times each night. This
relief was not forthcoming, and is really not a problem for me.
However, Mr. Strapp, principal of the school, approached me
Monday, and after outlining his nurse's duties requested an
assistant temporarily, pointing out that he was a hard of his
nurses "cracking up". I readily agreed with him that a relief
would be in order, as with nursing duties solely, Miss Carlson
has been hard pressed.

Since the night letter the German Measles has allowed
the eight days quarantine to elapse with no new cases so that
these all have been released. At present there are eight down
with the Influenza crisis, five of whom are at the peak of
the illness. Three others have discharging ears, which is an
aftermath of their infection. Miss Carlson, the nurse, insists
that she can carry on more easily, and Mr. Strapp has not broached
the subject of extra help since. Mr. Moore and I have discussed
the situation, and I have decided that until the principal brings
the subject to my attention, I will take no further steps re
nursing, of which you will be advised later.

In conclusion I may say that Mr. Strapp resents the fact
that no hospital room has been provided for his pupils, and in
every case of illness of any degree intimates that the Department
and myself must take the responsibility for undue results, and
practically insists that the patient be removed to hospital. The
latter injunction is governed by my judgement, but I do feel that
an infirmary for infectious and minor cases at Mount Elgin could
and should be equipped regardless of plans for a hospital at Muncey.

Yours very truly,

Dear Doctor Stone;

With further reference to the situation at Mount Elgin Residential School, I am pleased to report that the German Measles has been fairly well cleared up. That is to say we have gone beyond the regulation eight day quarantine period with no new cases. In all there were about 60 victims, with no complications, and two of the adult staff were involved.

The Influenza affair which disrupted our routine at Mount Elgin has also improved. One week ago I had three pupils in bed, and in all there were ten cases of Pneumonia. These are all recovering with the exception of one girl aged 16, whom I removed to Victoria Hospital at London on November 16th. This was done because of her grave condition in the school dormitory, and the fact that the heating system balked and for three days the school was real cold. It is a good thing that I removed her, which was done by ambulance, as her latest development is a tendency to pleural fluid which may call for surgery. One of the others in hospital underwent a rib resection for pus, and the third has recovered and returned to the school.

In each case of serious illness, in cooperation with Rev. O.B. Strapp, the parents were notified. We take not avail ourselves of an assistant nurse as the situation improved, and I feel that a portion of the hospitalization involved will be economically balanced thereby.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I would advise that it has been found necessary to discharge from Mount Elgin Residential School, Mary Ethel Dolson, aged 12 years, Muncey of the Thames band, who was admitted to that school on the 9th of September, 1936.

On October 1st, George Dolson, father of this girl appeared at this office complaining bitterly that his girl was not receiving enough to eat at the Mount Elgin School and that he wished her to be returned to her home. It would appear that this man had visited the school and attended at the noon meal and found that his child had no butter on her bread and no meat in the meal and that her dinner consisted of milk, bread (dry), 4 small potatoes, diced carrots and butter scotch pudding and in his opinion this was not enough and not to the standard that he fed her at home, when she received meat and butter at least twice a day.

On hearing his complaint, I asked Dr. McLeod to accompany me to the school and did learn that the claim of the man was right as to the meal he attended, but that the girl had not made any complaint to the principal or any of the staff that she had not received enough to eat.

In the presence of the Doctor, the principal and the matron and the dietician, this girl made the statement that she had only received meat at one meal in three weeks which was denied by the dietician, who maintained they served meat twice a week, which she did consider sufficient and that according to calories, the pupils were getting a well balanced diet and I can vouch that none of the pupils look underfed.

The father could not be convinced that his child was receiving good enough meals and rather than have further trouble with this parent who was adamant in his demands and at the request...
of the Principal I did instruct this girl to be discharged at once, contending that if the father was able to provide at home this was satisfactory and that the vacancy created would allow for another pupil to be placed in the school, as there are many applicants.

There has been a large number of truants from this school of late and in procuring the return of these pupils to the school and on enquiring as to why they ran away, Constable Bella of the R.C.M.P. has stated to me that some of these truants on being apprehended complain to him that they are not receiving enough to eat and being made to eat foods that they were not accustomed to and did not like and could not eat.

This complaint of the children can be understood to some extent, as no doubt the foods they receive at Mount Elgin are not of the same nature they had received at their homes, where they go in for a considerable amount of salt pork, and other heavy foods, which they, under the present system at Mount Elgin, do not receive.

Dr. McLeod is making a survey of the school as to the health conditions in general at the school and pending his report to you, I will speak to the Principal of the school to give attention to the feeding of his pupils, as I am informed that the children working in the kitchen are always well fed and it may be possible that these children take foods that should be given to the smaller pupils in the dining-room and that these small pupils go short and this would be the result of bad supervision by the officer of the school in charge and should be stopped by her. It is possible these children in the kitchen are playing favourite to their friends in the dining-room of other non-friends.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) A. D. Moore,
Indian Agent.

With further reference to pupils of the above school who were underweight, and your letter of the 5th instant, I have to report that I am quite pleased with the results obtained. My motive in writing December 28th, was not of complaint, but more to acquaint Dr. McGill with the fact that proposals made by the Principal to the Department, and passed along to me by Dr. McGill were not being carried out. I felt that the Department reasonably expected a separate dining room for underweight pupils had been inaugurated as promised, and should be made aware through me that nothing along this line had been done.

I do not believe that it would be advisable to write the Principal in view of the improvement made by these children. If under the present system normal weight is not maintained, to be revealed by periodic check-up on my part, a letter could be drafted at a later date.

There have been no major difficulties experienced with the Principal and staff of Mount Elgin Residential School by me. Nor once include the determination manifested of attempts to safeguard the pupils' health in methods other than those of your Medical Superintendent, the usual objection to the latter and those laid down by the Department being that they prove to be too great an inconvenience. This difficulty mainly involves the treatment of Trachoma, and the opportunity presented by the separate dining room proposal enabled me to bring the situation to the attention of Ottawa.
With the gratifying results obtained with weight production, I would prefer to let the same rest for the present. This is in view of the fact that the Principal has been ill, and in hospital, although now completely recovered.

If the occasion should warrant same due to weight loss, proper representation can be made to him both from the Department and myself at the time. Careful observation of the weight of pupils will be made, and it is my opinion that there will not be any great difficulty encountered in view of the excellent recovery of the children involved.

Dear Doctor Stone:

I have taken the plan of having Dr. Wall visit Caradoc Agency up with Mr. Strapp of Mount Elgin Residential School who informs me that his pupils are to be discharged for summer vacation on June 30th.

This date is earlier than in previous years, and it will eliminate the survey which I wished Dr. Wall to make. However, his services here will be appreciated on the reserve, and he can review the work at the school to advantage should he arrange to come as promised. Dear Doctor Stone;

I have to report the presence of Chicken-Pox at Mount Elgin Residential School. There are two cases, brothers, new pupils, and one suspect.

Source of the disease is unknown, and there are no cases on the local reserves. The usual precautions for isolation have been taken.

To date we have escaped infantile paralysis, which seems to be on the wane among the district white population.

Dr. Wall has concluded his survey and was pleased with the improvement noted in Trachoma at this Agency. I took him to Walpole Island this week, where we met Dr. Rowland, and visited the schools.

I have a letter from Dr. Brink stating that all his staff and himself have been assigned to the poliomyelitis outbreak, and that he would be unable to confer with me until this situation is in hand.

Muncey, Ontario, Feb. 3, 1938.

Dear Doctor Stone:

A survey of the pupils of day schools and Mount Elgin Residential reveals that there are many teeth which require dental attention. There are 151 fillings and 134 extractions indicated in the Agency Day Schools while at the Residential school there are 129 fillings and 113 extractions.

I would recommend that the services of a dentist be engaged for this work, and estimate that he would be required for a total of 14 working days equally divided between the day and residential schools. Any portion of this period, as funds permit, could be utilized to great benefit, as it is three years since a dental clinic was held at this agency.

As previously reported the chest clinic conducted for 155 residential school pupils, and 127 day school pupils, revealed but one case of active Tuberculosis. The latter, a day school pupil is being admitted to sanatorium, and the boy from Cape Croker Reserve admitted without chest X-ray and later found to be infectious has been returned to his home, from Mount Elgin Residential School.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Strapp:

The Department has received information concerning the medical service at Mount Elgin School, which leads to the belief that some small amount of friction is occurring. In case of a real emergency, if difficulty were experienced in getting in touch with Departmental officers there, the Department would make an exception if the circumstances were fully explained.

Muncie, Ontario,
October 11th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the outbreak of scarlet fever at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School, I would acknowledge receipt of your telegrams dated October 8th authorizing the procuring of additional nursing services. There are two proven cases at the school at the present time as well as approximately twenty suspects. One of the proven cases is the nurse manager, and the principal of the school advised me that help to take care of these patients was urgently needed. We are endeavouring to secure the services of a trained nurse to assume immediate duty. The pupils who have contracted the fever have been isolated in one dormitory at the school and all possible precautions to prevent spread of the disease have been taken.

In the opinion of the Medical Superintendent Dr. T. J. Jamieson all members of the Staff as well as the pupils are contacts and should be inoculated at the earliest possible date. There are only twelve vials of antitoxin on hand at the Medical Superintendent's office to do this inoculating and I am enclosing a requisition for 100 additional vials which should be forwarded to this office immediately. Dr. Jamieson has tried to obtain a supply of this antitoxin at the Public Health Institute at London but was refused on the grounds that we should arrange to secure our supply direct from Connaught Laboratories, Toronto but before committing the Department to this expense I would wish to have same approved.

Dr. Jamieson also wishes to receive your definite instructions as to the correct procedure to follow in procuring insulin or specific treatment for venereal disease as he has experienced difficulty in obtaining sufficient supply of these types of drugs. Anti-tetanus vaccine supplies have also been refused us by the Public Health Institute and we request information as to how we should procure same in future.

I shall report at a later date on the scarlet fever situation at Mount Elgin School.

Your obedient servant,

M. J. McCracken, In Charge Caradoc Agency.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find "Nurses" Monthly Account Form No. 363 amounting to $52.50 in favour of Miss Ruth Hill, R.R. #1, Middleport, Ontario, being payment for nursing services supplied at the Mount Elgin Indian Residential School for the period Oct. 13th to October 23rd, inclusive, 11 days at $7.50 per day.

Miss Hill was an Indian graduate nurse whom we obtained from Brantford as no other nurses were available and the services of a nurse were urgently needed at the residential school to cope with the scarlet fever epidemic. This was authorized in your telegram sent from Ottawa to this office on October 12th, 1941. I would recommend payment of this voucher.

I am glad to advise that Miss Hill became ill on October 24th and she was not able to continue her nursing at the school. We have secured the services of a graduate nurse from St. Thomas who is replacing Miss Hill but over fifty patients are in bed with this fever and additional help was necessary as the Doctor considered it was far too much work for one nurse. We therefore obtained an Indian woman from this Reserve to assist at the school and her services will not be as expensive as though we had engaged an extra nurse. At the present time there is, therefore, one nurse and an Indian woman on duty at the school whose services will have to be made a charge against the Department. I trust that this action will meet with approval and these services will be discontinued as soon as the scarlet fever shows signs of abating but at the present time new cases are continually being reported.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,

Dear Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th Instant, addressed to the Deputy Minister, and transferred to this office for reply.

In connection with the enquiry in regard to cattle infected with Bang's disease, or infectious abortion, I would say that this Department has not passed regulations for the control of this disease. It has an optional policy, which is available to live stock owners who must agree to comply with certain procedures, and, in return, the Department conducts blood tests and assists the owner in eradicating the disease in the herd.

In so far as this policy is concerned, the owners are not permitted to dispose of infected cattle except for immediate slaughter, or to purchasers who know they are infected animals.

There are, however, not more than 737 herds throughout the Dominion under this policy at the present time.

Dear Sir:

Re: Milk Pasteurization at Indian Schools

I have your letter of the 29th concerning the pasteurization of milk at the Mount Elgin Residential School at Muncey.

The communications between yourself and the Principal of this school have also been reviewed. Exception must be taken to the statement by the Principal to the effect that this office would be better engaged in persuading the farmers in that territory to clean up their herds and bring them to the standard of the herd at that school. While that, no doubt, is a desirable standard, there can be little doubt that the Principal has the mistaken idea of so many people, that if they have a healthy herd there is no danger from the milk. That is so far from the true situation that one would not expect it to call for any support.

I am also interested in your statement to the effect that you cannot obtain supplies for the installation of pasteurization plants during the war period. This is surprising in view of the fact that those dealers who are handling equipment for pasteurization plants inform us that they have no difficulty in making this material available to those who desire to purchase it. It would be unfortunate if any restriction of this nature were placed upon something which is so essential for public health. I must emphasize that while testing of the herds is a laudable procedure, it cannot be considered as by any means adequate. All the herds in the provincial institutions are likewise so examined but at the same time all the milk supplies from these herds are pasteurized. There is the additional situation which arises when your schools are in areas that are under compulsory pasteurization, such as the one at Muncey.

I shall be glad, as you suggested, to discuss this matter at any time with your Superintendent of Medical Services when he is in this city.

At approximately 1:00 p.m., this date information was received to the effect that SIMEN had a number of chickens hidden under his house on the Chippewa Indian Reserve, and that he had made an attempt to sell them for chickens. A police car was sent to the Chippewa Indian Residential School, and enquiries made to ascertain whether any chickens were missing from their flock; a count was taken, and it was determined that approximately 30 light Sussex chickens were missing.

A patrol was accordingly made to the house of SIMEN, where he was questioned and readily admitted the theft, and further that one ROBERT GRIMSHAW (Indian) Juvenile and Lloyd HUGHES (Indian) Juvenile, had assisted him in the theft. SIMEN and GRIMSHAW were placed under arrest, and an attempt was made to locate HUGHES, without result.

SIMEN informed the officer that the 30 chickens could be located in a potato patch under a tree of his house. They were subsequently found at the County Light Indian Residential School, where they were identified by a tattoo on the wings. Two of these chickens were dead, apparently having smothered to death in the cage that were used to carry them away from the school. The 30 chickens were handed over to Mr. G. S. STRAPP, Principal of the school.

SIMEN and GRIMSHAW were escorted to London, SIMEN being remanded in custody until 7-12-43. GRIMSHAW was placed in the Juvenile Detention Home, 645 York St., London, Ontario, and will appear in Juvenile Court on 10-12-43. In the meantime every effort will be made to locate HUGHES.

During the late P.M. of this date a further patrol was made of the Chippewa Indian Reserve, in an effort to locate HUGHES; however, he had not returned to his home, and nothing could be learned regarding his present whereabouts.

On this date SIMEN appeared in County Court at London, before Magistrate DUGGAN, and in answer to the charge entered a plea of GUILTY and was remanded in custody for sentence until 14-12-43.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Report by: Cady Claus.

June 14th, 1939, Victoria Hospital, London.

Was admitted to Hospital about 3:00 P.M., on Sunday, June 11th, 1939. A history was obtained of having fallen from a second story window. Child was unconscious at the time, on a bent Bradford frame with neck extension. Temperature was 104 per Axilla. Arms flexed - some nystagmus. Pupils dilated - no reaction to light. Respiration were deep with slight irregularity and mainly thoracic.

There was a large swelling on the right side of the head posterior to the orbit with bleeding from the ears and much mucous in the throat. Patient opened eyelids slightly at times. There was also marked twitching of the arms and legs if disturbed. The abdomen was somewhat distended.

It was considered that the child probably had suffered a severe fracture of the skull, most likely basilar. Also had a fracture dislocation of the 7th cervical vertebra. The patient was practically moribund on admission and the prognosis was felt to be nil. Due to poor condition and the fact that the patient was considered to be dying at the time, a complete neurological examination was not carried out.

The X-ray report was as follows: "No fracture of the skull was determined, but there was a fracture of the body and of the left articular process of the seventh cervical vertebra."

On discussing the case with the Radiologist, he gave the opinion that although no fracture of the skull was determined by X-ray, it was probable that the child had a fracture of the base, which, of course, would be diagnosed clinically.

The patient became worse - depth of unconsciousness became deeper and respirations became markedly embarrassed, especially during the twitching spells, which were more frequent. At 9:00 P.M., left leg showed to be spas tic and the right leg flaccid - bilateral ankle clonus was present - both pupils were dilated and fixed. Some external strabismus left eye. At 10:30 P.M., breathing was more shallow - pupils fixed - twitching much more frequent.

The treatment consisted of Bradford frame with halter extension, ice cap to the head, sponging for fever and restlessness, and stimulation, coramine etc.

The patient gradually became worse and died about 3:35 A.M., a few hours after admission.

A copy of the X-ray report is attached.

Diagnosis recorded is Fractured skull (base) and fracture of the 7th cervical vertebra.

L. G. Fellis,
Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

I regret to report an accident which resulted in the death of pupil #79X Courtland (Cody) Claus of the Brantford Superintendency.

Cody had been in bed for some days following an infected ear which had been discharging pus. On Sunday June 11th, the girls on hospital duty took his dinner up to him at about 12:10 P.M.. One of the girls, Lillian George, removed his pillow at about 12:25 P.M., and the other girl, Vella Seth, saw him in bed at about 12:35-40 P.M.

It is difficult to fix the exact time when the accident happened but three of the senior pupils, Lloyd Nicholas, Christine Henhawk, and Ruth Antone, were standing together at the corner of the girls' play-ground shortly before 1:00 P.M. when they saw him in mid air, falling. They rushed to where he was lying on the ground, picked him up carefully and carried him into the main building, where they met Mrs. Erratt our lady superintendent and Miss Stanley our nurse. A call was put in for Dr. McLeod. Meantime, our nurse took charge of Cody, and as he was unconscious, treated him for shock until the arrival of Dr. McLeod a few minutes later.

Dr. McLeod advised me that Cody's condition was serious and I telephoned Major Randle at Brantford asking him to notify Mr. Jesse Claus.

Cody was removed to the Victoria Hospital in London where X rays were taken. Little hope was held out for recovery as it was evident that there was brain injury and internal hemorrhage. Mr. Claus arrived about 9:00 P.M. and remained until Cody died.

I arranged with our local undertaker, Mr. Harding, to provide a casket and look after the body.

I called a Board of Inquiry with Mr. Agent Moore as Chairman at which Mr. Claus was present. The Mounted Police, Crown Attorney, and the Chief Coroner have all made their investigations and the decision was that the case was accidental and an inquest was unnecessary.

Following the Board of Inquiry I accompanied the body to the home of Mr. Jesse Claus.

I beg to remain,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Doctor Pardy: Re: Miss Helen Sonnea

Miss Helen Sonnea, age 14, was admitted to Staff Medicine on October 12th.

On admission she was very dyspnoeic, had a low grade temperature and X-ray of the chest showed consolidation of the lower half of the left lung.

She was put on sulfa therapy and her temperature became normal; the dyspnoea continued; the N.W. was 211 with albuminuria; the R.P. was 150 over 138; her W.B.C. 20,000. She was given saline and glucose intravenously and we were able to get the N.W. down to 157. Another portable X-ray of the chest was taken and the lesion on the left side was smaller but infection showed in the right base.

The patient became edematous and clinically showed signs of massive pulmonary edema. Her condition grew steadily worse and she died on October 30th.

We appreciate Mr. Soper's assistance in obtaining permission for an autopsy for us and the findings of Autopsy were as follows:

"Chronic pyelonephritis (bilateral); cardiac hypertrophy and dilatation; albuminous and fatty degeneration of myocardium; pulmonary oedema; lobular pneumonia; acute pleuritis (left); pleural effusion, pericardial effusion; ascites; subcutaneous oedema of legs and vulva; mural cardiac thrombi with purulent exudate; moderate passive congestion of liver and spleen; albuminous and fatty degeneration of liver. Multiple chronic duodenal ulcers, acute oesophagitis. Double ureter (left)?"

I am very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Allen:

I submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above Indian School which was visited June 18th while at the Caradoc Agency. Mr. E.H. Berthe worked at the school in the afternoon and did most of the detail checking of invoices, cancelled cheques, bank a/c, additions, etc. In the afternoon and evening we went both present and prepared the attached statements.

The Principal, Rev. O.B. Strapp, gave us every assistance including access to all records, and volunteered much information.

The period under review was the last Fiscal Year ending March 31st, and the cash book was balanced with the Bank Pass Book to that date.

Revenue - Cash Book - Cheques - Invoices & Bank A/c.

The cash book is the old synoptic type with only one column for revenue and receipts so it was necessary to analyse the revenue for the year and separate the grants from Farm and Garden proceeds, refunds, rebates, and miscellaneous. The Principal was advised of the new cash book and promised to send for one.

The total receipts were $36,417.15; the per capita grant is received about once a month indirectly from the Mission Board and not direct from the Department as at other schools. The total of these remittances was $19,004.15 which I do not think is the full amount due according to the per capita attendance.

The proceeds from Farm and Garden produce sold was $8,290.62, $1,444.52 being derived from the sale of eggs, and $6,846.10 from cattle sales, vegetables and miscellaneous products.

The item of $8,500.00 is in my opinion quite misleading being the estimated value of food consumed and produced.

N.C. Allen, Esq.,
Representative of the Treasury,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6210, file 468-24, part 1)
from the Farm and Garden. It is doubtful if quantities of meat, vegetables, milk, cream and garden stuff, all at present market prices, would realize that sum.

At other schools I have visited it has been suggested to the Principals that an approximate record be kept of quantities of food produced and consumed from the farm and garden, with current market prices, in order to obtain reasonably accurate ideas of this food value. The Principal admitted that no record was kept, but the sum as above had been placed on the books by the previous Principal for years past and he had merely followed precedent. He realized how inaccurate this might be, and intends to have a record kept of what is received in the kitchen for consumption. The item is offset under "Food" item and is shown separately under "Expenditures".

Expenditures

The item of Salaries $9,824.08 appears high; it is more than 51% of the per capita grant payments received. There are fifteen members of the staff for an average attendance of 153 pupils during the year, and extra labour for the year was $774.08.

The Fuel & Light item also appears high, although I was informed the old building requires much fuel to heat it in the winter season.

Farm and Garden expenses $5,685.50 includes several items incorrectly classified. For instance, the cost of a new car is included, also repairs and operating costs of the farm and truck which should really be apportioned between the farm and travelling and transport expense. The attention of the Principal was drawn to this.

Owing to losses occasioned by T.B. cattle, more cattle had to be purchased which also contributed to the Farm expense. New implements and farm equipment replacing old and worn out pieces were purchased, and considerable feed for cattle was an additional item due to insufficient quantities being produced last year.

The balance on hand at the close of the fiscal year was $289.91 with only current accounts payable.

Staff occupations and Salaries

The list of salaries being paid as at June 12th totalled $9,804.00 which approximates the actual total paid last year $9,824.08 but not including extra labour of $774.00.

Although conditions may warrant it here, the combined salaries of the mechanic, farm Instructor, herdsmen and utility man seem high, $2,260.00. Many of the residential schools in the west having more cattle and larger acreage under cultivation do not have men for each of these four occupations. The mechanic
and utility man's duties are one, and the farm instructor's and herdman's duties are combined also.

Cost of Operation

This statement is self-explanatory, but it appears exceptionally high compared to other schools due to the fact of the large "estimated" item of food consumed ($8,500.00) being included in the total expenditures.

This is clearly indicated by the item "cost of food per pupil for the year" $76.43, but if the food actually purchased is considered only, the amount per pupil for the year is $22.87 which is about normal.

The number of pupils in attendance as at June 12th was 154, and the average for the year 153.6.

Livestock & Crops

According to the Principal, the livestock includes 9 horses, 59 head of cattle, 61 hogs and 300 poultry. There are 20 hives of bees for the production of honey.

The crops produced in 1934 consisted of 932 bushels of oats and 1,905 bushels of potatoes. The root vegetables, hay, corn and greenfeed were not recorded, so there were no particulars available.

General

The books and records were in excellent order having been recorded neatly and accurately with the exception of a few expenses incorrectly classified and the matter of the haphazard way in which food values were estimated. A few suggestions were offered the Principal in regard to bookkeeping details which he seemed to appreciate and appeared keen and anxious to co-operate in any way possible.

The new cash book was put into effect after our visit last year but was written as from April 1st, 1936. This book provides a better record for revenue and receipts and the Principal is well pleased with it.

The reduction is due mostly to the sale of a large number of 300 cattle during the previous year. During the last year only two head of cattle had to be disposed of.

It will be noted that the estimated value of food produced and consumed was $4,270.73 as compared with $5,500.00 the previous year which was only a rough estimate as no records had been kept. During the last year a record has been kept and according to the principal the amount was $3,305.23, but after a close examination of the items it was observed that $3,934.50 covered hay, grain, corn, etc., etc., which had been fed to the stock, therefore only $4,370.73 represented the value of food produced and consumed.

The total of the monthly grants received by the school from the Mission Board amounted to $21,600.00 as compared with $19,004.15 during the previous year.

Salaries paid during the year amounted to $9,998.86 or 46% of the total grants received. There are seventeen members of the staff at present.
