I submit herewith a report of an audit of the books and records at the above-noted Residential School covering a period from May 1st, 1940 to April 30th, 1941.

I commenced my examination at 2:00 p.m., May 7th, 1941 and completed it the following day.

Cash Book, Cheques, Vouchers, Etc.

The paid cheques were examined and checked to the cash book. The paid vouchers were examined by test and compared with the entries in the cash book. The vouchers are filed in order of payment and they are also identified by the cheque numbers.

The cash book entries are neatly recorded and the allocations under the various headings are correctly made.

All casual receipts are covered by the issue of Standard receipts, the duplicates of which are available for checking purposes.

The deposits were verified with the duplicate deposit slips and the bank pass book.

Bank Reconciliation - April 30, 1941 - Statement No. 1

The bank account is kept with the Bank of Montreal, St. Thomas, some twenty miles from the school. According to the pass book, the bank balance at April 30th, was $127.65. The unrepresented cheques totalled $846.50, leaving a debit bank balance of $719.90. Cash on hand amounted to $15.18. Sheds for the new debit balance was $15.18, which agreed with the cash book. The bank account was overdrawn during a portion of each month during the year. The Principal made arrangements with the Bank to carry overdrafts and the interest charges for the period on overdrafts amounted to $11.65. The Principal feels the effect of the reduced grants and he will have to curtail his expenses to a minimum.

According to the Principal the School will not operate after June 30th. He has been instructed by the Secretary of the Church Mission Board to sell the farm implements and the livestock. The farm implements were sold by auction early in May and the sum of $4,375.96 was realized. This amount was deposited in the bank on May 3rd. It is anticipated the livestock will be sold in a similar manner on June 6th. The Principal expects to realize over $6,000.00 on the sale of livestock. According to the Principal the money realized from these sales will be used to liquidate the bank overdraft for which the Church is obligated.

As far as I could ascertain the accounts are paid promptly. The Principal proposes to notify all business houses with which he is doing business to render their accounts before the close of June in order to complete the payments by June 30th.

I have no information from Ottawa that the school is closing on June 30th.

The foregoing report, to the best of my knowledge and belief and from the books and records which were placed at my disposal, is a true and complete statement of the condition of the accounts at the time of my audit.

I wish to acknowledge the courtesy and the assistance extended to me by Mr. Soper during the course of my audit.

Dec. 20, 1947.

Mr. Earl Burch, driver of school bus now in operation, has approached me with a request for an increase in salary, complaining that with the almost daily increase in cost of living he cannot make ends meet and I feel that I must agree with him.

As a driver of a school bus, being an Indian, he is in a class by himself and, should he resign, he would be difficult to replace. We must keep in mind that he has the care and safety of the little children in his daily routine of travel. I therefore asked him what he might expect in the way of an increase; he said at least $25.00 a month. I think his request is very reasonable and do not hesitate to recommend it. His present salary is $100.00 a month for a twelve month service. During the summer holidays and all other school holidays he is used as a utility man for their rentals to the various schools and I have found his service very helpful.

Dear Sir:

A temporary exempt position of Chauffeur was established by the Treasury Board on March 27, 1947, for the Indian Affairs Branch at a salary of $100 per month. The incumbent of this position was engaged to drive a school bus at the Caradoc Indian Agency, Muncey, Ontario. It was necessary for the Department to provide transportation for several children attending school from different sections of the Agency. The bus is the property of the Department. When not engaged in taking pupils to and from school the driver of the bus is employed as utility man in making repairs to the bus and other motor equipment at the Agency. In the summer season he is employed by the Indian Agent driving a truck and tractors in agricultural operations. The incumbent of this position has recently requested an increase in salary to $125 per month.

As two school buses are now required at the Caradoc Agency, the Department will be employing two chauffeurs. Will you please advise me as to the prevailing rate for this class of employment in the Muncey District. I think Chauffeur and Truck driver would be a better designation of the position. The village of Muncey is approximately 20 miles from London, Ontario.

Yours sincerely,

Director,

Lake Superior Mission.

Proposed Industrial Home for Indian Children at Garden River.

Algoma District.

It will be remembered probably by some that during the summer of 1874, "Chief Little Pine" from Garden River visited Toronto, Hamilton, and St. Catharines, and at several meetings which followed, the Indians there gave an enthusiastic response to the proposition made to them by the Rev. Mr. Macdonald to establish a mission school at Garden River.

This was the commencement of a movement which has since developed into an organized scheme for the betterment of the Indians of the Garden River district.

The first step taken was to raise funds for the purpose. This amount was appreciated by some who subscribed generously, and in addition a little money was raised among the whites, and with this money, during the ensuing winter, the commencement, a commenced a mission school at Garden River, which soon attracted considerable attention.

The next step (1875), Chief Bukkinkama (leader of the Lake Superior band) appointed the missionary.

A second school was opened in the fall of the same year, and a third was opened in the spring of 1876, and a fourth in the fall of 1877.

The Garden River Mission is now under the management of the Church Missionary Society, but it receives an annual grant from Canada and Ontario Government.

The school is situated on the banks of the Garden River, about one mile from the town of Toronto, and two miles from the nearest telegraph office.

A farm consisting of about six acres is attached to the mission and is being cultivated by the Indians.

Among other industries the boys will be taught how to make canoes, and a school for the instruction of boys will be opened.

The proposed Industrial Home is as follows:

1. A substantial building will be erected in connection with the present premises, containing Dining Hall, School Room, sleeping rooms, etc., and will accommodate about 25 children (boys and girls) as Boarders.

2. A farm consisting of about 30 acres will be purchased for the mission purposes, and will be worked by the Indians.

3. The present school will be enlarged to about 15 acres.

4. A school teacher is already engaged who has been in the boarding trade, and will continue to do so.

5. This industry will be carried on by a carpenter living on the spot who undertakes to teach the boys his trade in the evenings.

In conclusion of his having the free use of the building for carrying on his own business.

This enterprise is to be looked upon as a noble and commendable plan on our part. The good effect and results which such a plan would produce cannot be overestimated.

It is therefore recommended that the foregoing plan be carried out, and we trust that the friends who have already subscribed will continue to do so, and that others will be induced to do so.

We believe that the Indians will be benefited by this plan, and that the cost will be less than the value of the land, buildings, and implements.

We hope that the members of the Church will be able to compete with their white neighbors, and that the Indians will be enabled to earn a livelihood from the land.

Lake Superior Mission

Proposed Industrial Home for Indian Children at Garden River,
ALGOMA DISTRICT.

It will be remembered probably by some that during the summer of 1874, Chief "Little Pine" from Garden River visited Toronto, Hamilton, and St. Catharines, and in his mission addressed the Indians who knew the wants of his people, namely—“that a big teaching-wagon might be built at Garden River, where the children of the Indians of the Great Ojibway Lake might be taught and clothed, and fed.”

This was the commencement of a movement which has since developed into an organized scheme for the establishment of an Industrial Home for Indian children at Garden River.

During Chief “Little Pine’s” tour, the sum of £213.10s. was raised; this amount was supplemented by several generous donors, who sent us sums of £5 each, and others, and several sums from the Old Country; and with this money, during the ensuing winter, by way of encouragement, the Reverend Mr. Wilson built a house (20 feet), at a cost of £64—which is now attended by about 30 scholars.

The next summer (1875), Chief Bukwejenjewa, together with “Little Pine,” again visited Toronto, Hamilton, and St. Catharines, and he also was so successful as to raise the sum of about £740 towards the carrying out, in full, of this scheme. As a result of this visit, Mr. Wilson was enabled to superintend the disposal of the funds and to receive and account for any annual contributions that might be received. The Secretary, the Reverend Mr. Wilson, writes: “Esq., Ware, Hertford.”

The Garden River Mission is not now specially connected with any Home Society, but it receives an annual grant of £50 from the Alder Board of the Synod of Toronto, and £10 from the Indian Department. For its future support it is dependent entirely upon the benevolence of friends.

The plan proposed for an Industrial Home is as follows—a plain substantial building is to be erected in connection with the present parsonage, containing Dining-room, Kitchen, School-room, and Bedroom for two missionaries about 20 children (boys and girls) as Boarders.

A farm consisting of about 40 acres has already been set aside for mining purposes, and will be worked by the Indian boys under the direction of a farm man; about 14 acres were cleared by the Indians last fall, a few acres are still under cultivation, and the remainder will be sown in the spring, and the cleared part planted. For their education the children will be marched down to the school-house at Garden River, where they will be joined by day-schoolers from the vicinity.

Among other Industries the boys will be taught boat-making, carpentry, &c., and a teacher will be engaged for these purposes. A good school teacher is already engaged who has been in the boat making trade, and so will be able to give instruction in both. A teacher and a carpenter living on the spot will undertake to teach the boys how to make merely in consideration of his having the free use of the building for carrying on his own business.

This everything is to be conducted upon as simple and economical a plan as possible. The parsonage will consist simply of a room, a school-room, and a kitchen (two rooms), merely of a form man, schoolmaster, and cook (who will be paid), and the present farm will be already engaged, having been purchased by Mr. Wilson from England. Their salaries are to be provided for through the kindness of friends, and the surplus provided for through the benevolence of those who have already been asked for in ANNUAL SUPPORT FOR THE CHILDREN.” The estimated cost of the building is £100, and the estimated cost of the land is £10 for four acres. Several friends in the town have already very kindly offered to undertake the expenses of board of a few children, and the Rev. Mr. Wilson, Rural Dean, undertakes one, Rev. Mr. Davison a second, Rev. Mr. Davidson a third, from their respective Sunday Schools.

It is our earnest hope that in reply to this appeal other friends may rise to assist us, so that the good old Chief’s wish may be thoroughly carried out.

Practical people will understand that to set well on foot such a plan as we propose would require economy, a non-expense of the utmost necessity being made; not only have the buildings to be erected, but the land (not yet cleared) and the farm to be purchased, and for the successful carrying on of farming operations there ought to be some little surplus fund in hand. We therefore respectfully submit our plan, and respectfully beg to be thought unreasonable if we suggest that the funds required may be obtained by the sale of such as may be thought useful for the purpose of the undertaking. We believe that the sale of cattle or furniture for the market, or live stock or implements of culture for the farm, or even anything really useful will be greatly appreciated.

We trust our friends will assist this our undertaking in one way or another, and their consideration and support, now so much needed, will be greatly appreciated. This district of Algoma is opening up rapidly to the white settler, and the poor Indians, if they do not avail themselves of the opportunity, will be left behind by the tide of emigration or else tempted to go among the whites, where they will be more likely to be able to earn a livelihood by working on farms and units with the reaping machines from the till which God has bestowed upon us all.

Some people may say, and may say that it is the fate of aborigines to disappear before the advance of the “pale face,” and that our efforts for their good must prove futile—aye! while the world endures there will be those who will be willing to do what they can for the advancement of the race. If it be a mistake may God judge us and not man. If it prove successful we shall be glad, and if not, we shall be grateful that we have made the attempt.

Any further information will be given and contributions will be thankfully received by the Rev. Stephen Wilson, D.D., Colwood; or by the Missionary, the Rev. Edward F. Wilson, M.A.

GARDEN RIVER, ALGOMA,

March 11th, 1876.

Sir,

I had the honor to address you in connection with the late administration in reference to the Industrial Home for Indians situated at Garden River in the district of Algoma. At the time of the erection of the building during the last summer, I applied the Department for the grant of an annual sum towards its support. The children to be educated therein. The application was forwarded and reported on before I retired by the Deputy Superintendent, but before any answer had been given a sad calamity happened by which the structure or the building connected with it were all burnt to the ground.

It is much to be feared that the present administration will look unfavorably upon my renewed application for assistance towards the rebuilding of the Industrial Home on a somewhat larger & more comprehensive scale than the former one, and will also demand an annual payment by the Department toward the support of certain institutions of the Native Children to be trained therein.

I beg therefore to lay our plans before you for your kind consideration.

(1) The locality. We propose to build the new Institution in the immediate neighborhood of Baillie St. Marie, which is a good central point heavy of access.

We have now 50 children in the Home. Of these 21 are supported by Sunday Schools, 10 by individuals, and 19 by Government.

NO DEBT.

Through the blessing of Almighty God, funds have been supplied us to meet all our expenses thus far, and our accounts last October, at the close of the first year showed a balance in hand of $200.61.

ANNUAL COST.

A general fund is required to meet the expenses of the Principal, Matron, Schoolmaster, Medicine, Repairs, &c., which together amount to about $2,500.00 per annum. The children cost $75.00 each per annum for board and clothing; hence 75 by 50 equals $3,750 plus $2,500 gives $6,250.00 as the entire cost per annum of the Institution at the present time. Of this amount we receive $1,642.00 from friends in England, $1,140 for the support of 19 children (50% paid by the Indian Department), $584.00 from the Col. & Capt. Church Society, $600.00 from the Algoma Diocesan Fund, $800.00 for the support of individual children at $75.00 each per annum, $500.00 for little girls ($50.00 clothing being supplied) and $100 for one child educated as a Teacher. Total, $5,000. The balance of $754 has to be made up by general contributions and by gifts of clothing, &c.
CLOTHING.

This past winter we have run very short of clothing, and during the past half year have exceeded our allowance by $64. Several Sunday Schools that contribute only the $10 board money for their proteges have failed to send the required supply of clothing, so that we have been obliged to purchase from the general fund. Very few of the children were supplied by their supporters with warm underclothing, which in this rigorous climate is an absolute necessity. Unless we are liberally supplied with good warm clothing we fear it will be impossible to keep the children at the present low rates charged to their supporters. At the same time we would heartily thank those Sunday Schools, individuals, and friends both in Canada and England who have made the things and filled the boxes and bales—the opening of which is so great a pleasure to us. We feel sure that none of our helpers would wish to see their children in rags, or that their toes should be frozen for want of warm socks and mocassins.

INDUSTRIES.

We are endeavoring to make the industries—that is the farm, carpentering, bootmaking, laundry, and workroom pay themselves, and so far have every cause for encouragement—but at the same time there is of course a certain amount of risk in carrying on these various branches, and it seems to be only right that we should as soon as possible form a reserve fund, from which to draw when it becomes necessary to increase the stock in either branch. So soon as the industries are well established and begin to yield a regular income to the Home, it is intended that additional children shall be supported from this source.

PROPOSED SEPARATE GIRLS' HOME.

It is proposed to erect a new Home for girls and to confine the present building entirely to boys. Our friends in England are entirely in favor of the movement, and a paper is already in circulation there asking for contributions to the amount of $8,500, which sum it is thought will be sufficient both for building and furnishing a Home for the accommodation of about 20 girls. A Christian lady will be engaged to undertake the education and general care of the girls, and a laundress and seamstress will also be employed. When the two Homes are in operation the annual expenditure will be increased by about $1,000 independent of the support of children.

For the present it is proposed to rent a building for the girls, so that the new plan will (D. V.) come into operation.

AFTER THE SUMMER HOLIDAYS.

As soon as funds will admit of it we hope to introduce several new industries for the boys, such as printing, tailoring, boat-building &c., and we hope

MORE SUNDAY SCHOOLS

will come forward to undertake the support of fresh children. We would like if possible to begin with 40 boys and 20 girls after the holidays, and the boys may in time be very well increased to 60 or 70 if supporters can be found.

We feel that it is indeed no small undertaking that is before us, but God has greatly blessed us hitherto, and we believe that He will continue to bless us and to prosper His own work. We therefore simply lay before you our plans and explain to you our position in the hope that

INCREASED EFFORTS

may be made to enable us to carry on and render more useful this work in which we are engaged.

CONTRIBUTIONS

may be sent either by cheque, or bills enclosed in a letter and registered to

General Regulations.

1. The Shingwauk Home is a Church of England Institution for the Christian training and education of Indian boys.

2. The Home is supported (with the exception of a Government grant) by voluntary contributions from friends of the cause, each boy being $75 per annum if no clothing is supplied, $95 per annum if all but socks and hats are supplied, and $140 per annum if all clothing is supplied. Donations ranging $15 to $100 may be made in addition to the support of each boy; a general fund is required, for the payment of salaries and general expenses.

3. Indian boys will be received at about ten or eleven years of age, and it is intended that they shall remain till they are fifteen. They will attend school, first two years, then half school and half Board, then Board only. During the first two years they will be entirely at school. The third year they will be half school, half at trade. The last two years they will be paid an apprentice's wages. All boys who are under sixteen years of age are paid a school allowance of two dollars, amounting to $100 during their period of residence.

4. Sundry articles or individuals intending to support a boy are asked to give advice (boots, socks and clothing ($25), shoes ($5), shirts ($1), breeches ($7); for the purchase of provisions, and towards the cost of clothing and the pay of the boy will be charged to the trade at which they reside.

5. For boys intended for teachers or the ministry the charge will be $100 per annum for board and schooling after the second year of their residence.

6. Clothing will be issued for one year two suits of sleeping clothes, one hat, one winter cap, two pairs of boots, one pair overcoats, four pairs of socks, three shirts, two undershirts, two pairs of drawers, four pocket-handkerchiefs, one muffler, one pair of gloves.

7. Parents will be expected to sign an agreement stating the terms for which they are willing for their children to remain in the institution, before they can be admitted.

8. Parents requiring their children to return home will provide clothing for them to have in.

9. Boys are allowed to return home for their holidays in the summer, provided the promised money for them to do so, and they are furnished with free tickets to prevent the expenditure, but it is expected that they should be back punctually at the regular time, and not more than once.

10. Boys of the age of seven or nine and less than thirteen years old may commence learning trades, working half the day only, and will receive a little pocket-money if they work satisfactorily. $4 per month will be allowed to the trade for learning trades.

11. Boys of the fourth year will work all day (if required) at their trade, and will receive two weeks' wages, each, and five, to their savings accounts, and the balance will be charged to the trade. $4 per week will be charged to the trade, $20 per annum to the Savings Bank, and $10 per annum to the General Fund of the Institution.

12. Boys of the fifth year, working as above, will receive $6 per week wages, and $10 to their savings bank account, in addition to the wages and the balance remaining charges, $4 per month will be charged to the trade, the balance of $1 being up plus a General Fund.

13. No time will be put on the pay-roll until they have signed an agreement promising to keep the institution.

14. Boys who are leaving before their term is expired are liable to forfeit their proper share of Savings Bank, and parents removing their children, or keeping them at home contrary to agreement, are liable to have the cost of their clothing charged to them.

15. Boys who have passed their course creditably at the Shingwauk Home and government, and their teachers will receive a certificate to that effect (in leaving, and others who are made to prove their unsuitability.

16. The Shingwauk Home is now regarded as associated with the Wawanosh Mission (for girls) and all regulations will be so framed as to be applicable to the boys of both Homes; the Treasurer also shall not neglect the funds placed in his hands, as he cannot be held responsible for the use of the same.

Towards the support of individual boys we receive a grant from the Department of £1200 per annum—that is—for the support of 20 boys at £60 each—which sum pays for their food and in part for their clothing—but leaves little or nothing to meet the salaries of teachers, and of such other annual expenses.

Besides the 20 boys supported by the Department—we receive support for about 25 more from Sunday Schools and other sources.

But it is felt General Maintenance of the Institution has been an enormous strain.
of increased help. Up to the present time we have endeavored to manage with as small a staff as possible. For about three years we managed this without a matron, the school master himself experimenting all the domestic arrangements of the institution with merely one woman servant as cook. As the number of the boys increased this became impossible. We engaged a matron. Then up to last spring I undertook all the account keeping myself for the two homes—separate accounts for each separate trade, Savings Bank accounts. This, with teaching a senior class every day under tints, the general management proved too much for me and I broke down.

I have now engaged a man who will devote half his time to the printing office, or half his time to account keeping & general management of the boys when at work (apart from his school studies). This will be an additional expense to the Institution, but it seemed to be a necessity for the proper carrying on of the work.

OUR INDIAN HOMES.

With our finances at a low ebb, it is necessary that every expense should be kept down as much as possible, and consequently the closing of the Indian Homes for the present season (we close our books now the 31st December instead of the 30th September) will be condensed into as few pages as possible.

The obvious cause of the low state of our funds is that our income has not increased in proportion to the increase of our work. It is no small matter to keep two Institutions in active operation—a Girl's Home with some 20 or 25 girls to clothe and feed, and three persons employed to teach and keep them; and a Boy's Home with from 60 to 80 boys, and eight persons employed in caring for and teaching them, and instructing them in various trades. Even with the greatest economy, and the kind assistance we receive in gifts of clothes for the children, the entire expenses amount up every year to about $160 a week; (i.e.—about £290.) We have never yet been able to receive so large a number of children as that mentioned above, the greatest number ever received being 18, and of boys 32.

The whole of this work of caring for these poor Indian children, and training them in the ways of christianity and civilization, has grown up within the short period of six years. The Shingwauk Home, for boys, was opened on the 1st of August 1875, and the Wawonish Home, for girls, (they are about 24 miles apart,) was opened on the 19th of August 1879.

We desire in this Report to tell, in as few words as possible, what the Homes are doing, and have done since they came into existence, and then leave it with the Christian public to say whether they are an object worthy of increased support. God has blessed and helped us wonderfully so far. It has been perhaps on the whole a struggling uphill work, but it is really worth while in looking back to see how difficulties once often seemingly have either vanished or been overcome; how when our path seemed mapped up, the way has been opened before us. We have never had to beg for money, our people have been simply to make known our wants once more, as they have arisen, and then do their best to put it into the hearts of His people to supply them. Just at the present time our want is an income sufficient to meet the annual expenditure of the two Institutions. We have already a considerable surplus of funds for the Shingwauk Home, the old set and the original Institution, and it seems most desirable that a second set should be established for the collection of funds for the Wawonish Home. We believe that some help would undoubtedly be collected in England, very about £100 per annum specially for the Girl's Home—Then as to Canada, what we seem mostly to want is some organized plan for the collection of annual subscriptions for the General Fund of the two Institutions. A large number of the individual Indians are already supported separately by Canadian Sunday Schools. This seems an excellent plan, if only the children will not tire in their good work, and will send in their quarterly remittances as promptly as possible. We should be glad if 20 more Sunday Schools would at once each commence the support of an individual child, £75 (£13) per annum is the cost, or if nothing is sent £50. But in addition...
In this individual support of Indian children, we want to see a generous subscription list set up in Canada, for the support of the two Homes. We have already a few names of annual subscribers, but the list needs to be very largely increased in order to come near our aim. Indians who are able to do so would perhaps try to send us $10 per annum; others might try to send that amount, and country Sunday Schoolers, whose Sunday collections would not admit of their supporting an Indian child, might perhaps send us $10 or $20 per annum to our General Fund.

Now for a few words about the Shingwauk Home. There are at present about 50 boys on our roll list, but owing to the death of the Principal in the spring and the consequent partial closing of the Institution, there are only 17 boys at present in residence, and the money which would otherwise have been used in the support of the full number has been employed in the erection of the new wing, which adds greatly to the comfort and usefulness of the building. It was possible to build another wing at the other end of the Institution containing a junior schoolroom and dormitory, and reading room for the apprentices, all of which are now finished, and also a chapel, but there remains little prospect of carrying out any of these plans just as planned. Of the boys who left us in the spring, several had completed their full term with us as apprentices at various trades, and are expected to get employment among non-Indian people, while a tailor, two were fishermen, two prospectors, one a bootmaker, one a blacksmith, and one a carpenter. Two boys also had become fitted as teachers; of these one is now the catechist and school master at the new Mission among the Indians of the Red River District, the other has charge of an Indian school near Parry Sound. We hope that the Missionaries in charge of the Mission stations to which our boys belong, will after they have completed their course with us, look after them and assist them both in getting and retaining situations at work for which they have become fitted. Our boys make capital workmen, and give great satisfaction to their employers, but it is only to be expected that they will need some encouragement and assistance from those friendly to their race when they first come out into the world to make their own way. The spirit of industry, thrift, and determination to work, may be gathered from an extract from a letter written by one of the boys who is now making farming his vocation, but expects to come back to us next spring.

The Wawanoosh Home, for girls, has been placed under the fostering care of a local ladies' committee, the members of which all take very great interest in the working of the Institution. Mrs. Macdonald, the Superintendent's wife, though a great invalid and seldom able to leave her sofa, has quite made it her work in life to care for the poor Indian girls, and kindly occupies the position of first Lady Manager. A full report of the work from her pen will appear in the Annual Missionary News, but from the reasons given above only a very little can be said in this condensed report, which for economy's sake we wish to confine to 24 pages, and of which about 500 copies only will be printed. Mrs. Macdonald says—

"Our Wawanoosh Home which has now been fully opened a year and a half (though the wing of the building had been occupied by a few girls the two previous years) has prospered. The girls are hardworking and receiving in all domestic duties in proportion to their ability. We have now 16 girls, whereas this time last year we had but 14. The exterior of the Home is becoming as attractive as the well ordered interior, the lot consisting of five acres."

The average number of marks taken by the pupils was higher than at any previous examination. At the midsummer examination 1879 the pupils averaged 574 per cent of the total number possible; at Christmas 1880 564 13-18 per cent; at midsummer 1881 613 per cent; and at the examination just held 632-26 per cent.

The subjects taken up were as follows:

3 senior boys were examined in geography, grammar, arithmetic, English history, English, algebra, Latin, and a little Greek.

12 boys and seven girls in reading, spelling, dictation, arithmetic, geography, grammar and English history, the girls omitting the last two subjects and taking sewing, knitting &c., instead.

14 more boys and 7 girls brought up the 2nd reading book, spelling, dictation, arithmetic, and a little elementary geography. The rest of the school were only commencing to read, and writing on slates.

The following are a few specimens of the questions given to the senior boys and the answers they gave.

(a) Describe the Tabernacle. Ans. (Esquimaux.) The Tabernacle was a church made something like a tent. This is the church which the Jews had while journeying through the wilderness. It was 30 cubits long, 10 cubits wide and 10 cubits high. It was divided into two parts, the larger part was called Holy Place, and the smaller part Holy of Holies. In Holy Place form the services, but inside the Holy of Holies only the High Priest was allowed to go once a year. In Holy Place the altar of incense, the table of shew bread and the golden candlesticks were kept. In Holy of Holies the Ark of the Covenant was kept.

(b) Tell what you know about Melchizedek. Where is he mentioned in the New Testament? Ans. (Perkins.) He blessed Abraham when he came from the battle after he had got Lot, for he was made prisoner. He was king of Salem and also a High Priest, and no one knew who he was. He is mentioned in Hebrews vii.

(c) Where are Aden, Puducherry, and Singapore? Ans. (Kahngwa.) Aden is at the mouth of the Red Sea. Puducherry is in India, on the Coromandel coast. Singapore is on the Straits of Malacca.

(d) What is told of Edward VI? Ans. (Williams.) He became King when he was 10 years old. Quick and intelligent. Somerset managed the kingdom when he was a boy. He built schools at Shrewsbury, Birmingham, Macclesfield. Also hospitals of St. Bartholomew and St. Thomas.

The marks gained by the pupils included those given for good conduct, punctuality &c., as well as for progress in their trades, so that the apprentice boys (who only study at night) had an equal chance with the rest.

The following is a letter written during the examination by one of the apprentices—

Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste Marie,
Dec. 15th '81.

Dear Sir,—I thought I would write to you this evening and tell you what I am doing. We are very busy the whole day and return to the Home about 6 o'clock in the evening. There are at present 2 boys learning tailoring, 3 learning carpentry, 6 printing, 3 blacksmithing, 3 timbersmithing, 4 bootmaking, and 1 harnessmaking.

The following are specimen letters from their employers—

(From the Blacksmith.)
Sault, Dec. 15th '81.

Rev. E. F. Wilson,

Dear Sir.—I am pleased to be able to say that the whole of the boys in my employ are making very fair progress, and that they are always anxious to oblige in every possible manner, and give entire satisfaction to myself.

I remain,
Very respectfully,
William Brown.

(From the Tailor.)
Sault, Dec. 15th '81.

Rev. E. F. Wilson,

Dear Sir.—In reply to your note starting from the Shingwauk Home I have to say that I've been Maxwell...
I am yours truly,

W. Vaughan.

(From a Carpenter in the Village)

Rev. E. F. Wilson

Dear Sir,—It gives me great pleasure to say that the boy William since he came to work for me has been punctual, obedient, and hardworking, and deserves the best character that could be given to anyone in his situation. He has given perfect satisfaction in every particular.

Yours respectfully,

H. Storey.

Other tradesmen speak equally well of the capabilities and behaviour of the boy, and it may be taken as an established fact that Indian boys are fully capable of becoming good mechanics if a fair chance is given them to do so. It surely then would be far better that increased facilities should be afforded to the rising generation of Indians to engage in occupations for which they are as well fitted, than that they should be left to idle away their time in a semi-civilized, half-gipsy sort of existence on the Indian Reserve. His Excellency the Marquis of Lorne, who visited the Institution last summer, was exceedingly pleased with all that he saw, and expressed his belief that our plan of dealing with the boy and encouraging him to throw off their Indian habits and amalgamate with the white population was the right course to pursue. His Excellency the Earl of Dufferin, who laid the foundation stone of the present Shingwauk Home in 1874, received a more satisfactory account of the work done there than we have ever heard of from any other institution.

We are not at present gaining their hearts by giving them food, and care for them as though they were our own family, and through the medium of their local agents make known to them the importance of working and earning their own living.

TO OUR SUPPORTERS

We most heartily thank our many friends and benefactors for the kind help they have afforded us during the past year, and trust that they will continue to do so.

For the sake of the Indians making progress and gaining self-support, we appeal to all who can afford to do so to contribute to this responsible undertaking.

Sir,

I have had the honor of addressing several letters to the Department in reference to the difficulties we have had in securing a regular attendance of pupils at our institutions, and have also recently paid a visit to Ottawa in order to press the matter upon the attention of the Department.

From what I know personally of the condition of Indian schools throughout the Province of Ontario, I feel that there has been employed little energy in the education and training of Indian children; it seems to me that there is most urgent need for some increased pressure...
being brought closer upon the Indian parents —
whether by Compulsion or by milder means — so
as to secure a regular attendance at the schools,
and a better return for the great expenditure
incurred both by the Department and by
Missionary Societies.

It surely is not a satisfactory state of things
that in a district where there are 50 or 60 children
of a schoolable age, the average attendance at
school should be but from 10 to 15, — that
at an Institution such as ours, with accommodation
for 60 boys & upwards, we should have only
between 20 and 30. But these should be such
difficulties in inducing the Indians to allow their
children remain a period of five years;—
and that agreement when signed should be
continually broken. But I have said
Sufficient already on these points in my former communication - and I feel satisfied that the heads of the Institution will readily cooperate all that I have said.

It seems time that the only way to bring about an improvement is for the Department of State to take up the matter, and that that course may be brought promising if there are any further suggestions in addition to those which I have already ventured to put forward.

I would propose first (as I have already said)

1) A thorough government inspection of both day schools and institutions - such inspection being but a new to assuring that the school are properly attended - the teachers efficient scholars taught good lessons - and advance in their knowledge of the English language.
(2) That a system of fines be introduced for non-attendance at School—

These fines I would suggest might be imposed as follows:

The inspection of the schools should take place just before the half yearly payment of annuities.

The annuity money would be forfeited by pupils

(a) Between the ages of 11 and 13 who were unable to read & spell intelligently from the 2nd reader, write a fair hand 75¢—

(b) Between 13 and 15 who were unable to read & spell from the 3rd book, do arithmetic up to a certain point, answer questions in geography, write a letter and speak intelligible English.

(c) By young men between 15 and 18 who failed to pass an examination in the
foregoing subjects - and who had not learned or become apprenticed to a trade.

The annuity money to be forfeited to be either:
(a) divided among the members of the Band (those who forfeited it being excluded)
(b) or be used for the improvement of the School building and the purchase of School supplies
(c) or be expended in prizes, medals etc. to be awarded to the most efficient pupils.

(Cases of sickness could, of course, be excused by a doctor's certificate)

I venture to think that the effect of introducing some such system as this would be to produce a far more regular and satisfactory attendance at the Day School & the Institution. It would make the Indians on the Small Reserves more anxious than they are now to have schools erected - when they have been kept in constant operation - it would
also I believe be a means of infusing fresh life and spirit into the teachers.

I would also renew my former proposals that in addition to this—a system of rewards should be instituted in the form of medals or government certificates—which would lead to enfranchisement.

The idea (as I have suggested in former letters) would be for the Indian children to attend the day schools till 10 or 11 years of age, and then under the direction of the Inspector, to be drafted for the Institutions. Should the institutions now in existence—viz Muncy, Mohawk, Wikwemikong, Shingwauk, and Wanabek be found insufficient to accommodate, it could I suppose easily be enlarged—or new erected.

EASTER HOLIDAYS.
Four days, Good Friday to Easter Tuesday inclusive.

Two Weeks, During which there will be only school for juniors from 3 to 5 p.m., other classes 7.15 to 8.30 p.m. Those not at school to work on farm, garden, wall-building etc., receiving 10, 15, or 20 cents per day according to merit. Bosses 25 cts.

Our Object:

Our object in issuing this little paper, which will be printed from time to time as funds admit, is to draw attention to the following facts:

1st. That there are in this country, scattered throughout the Dominion of Canada 139,000 Indians.

That as time goes on and our West expands, these Indians necessarily come more and more into contact with us.

We must now that the wisest, most just and humane course for us in Canada to pursue would be at once to establish Institutions on a large scale where Indian children would be received and educated and brought up in the habits of the white man, so that when they grow up they may be enabled to stand up among their neighbors, to resent and to remove the question again comes to the fore. What are we to do with these wild men of the forest, the original owners of all soil which they have discarded their all their rights and drive them into the wilderness or else we must provide for their existence in our midst and admit them into our civilization. There seems to be little doubt but that this Indian question will become more and more difficult and serious as time goes on.

The advance of the iron road through the North West has produced a demand to do with the Indian question as little as possible. The insidious influence of the Red and his half breed friends is felt even in the heart of the Indian country. Here in Canada we have a million only of white population and 130,000 Indians. We in Canada have just half the number of Indians that they have in the United States; the Indians therefore are in far greater proportionate numbers with us than they are across the border. As our population increases we must necessarily come more and more into collision with them. The United States Government has spent an enormous amount of money in trying to reduce the Indians to subjection by compelling them by force not to interfere with the advance of white immigration. But time has made the Americans wiser; they have found that killing the Indians and driving them westward does not pay, the process has been too expensive. Within the last eight or ten years they have completely changed their policy. They have realized that it is cheaper to expend large amounts of money and sacrificing the lives of many of its best soldiers in reducing the Indians to subjection by force of arms, is now subsidizing in a liberal generous manner a number of large Institutions which for the most part have been originally started by philanthropic people or charitable societies. The success that has attended the Institutions, which already exist, both in this country and the States, goes far to show it. If the Indians are to become our fellow citizens, and to unite with us in building up this great country, it surely seems the wisest and most generous course on our part, to afford their children the advantages of a liberal education, and to put them in the way of gaining their own livelihood, as we do ourselves. A little money spent now, both by government and by our wealthy fellow citizens, may be the means of saving much expense, and perhaps many lives, in the future.

A Large Protestant Institution At Sault Ste Marie

SAULT STE. MARIE is a splendid centre for Indian work, and that is where the two Indian Institutions, called the Shingwauk Home and the Wawatam Home are situated, established. There is no better central position could be found. It is already the crossing point of eight or ten different steamboat lines, and we expect within two years time it will be the centre of four railway lines, two connecting us with the States and two with Eastern Canada. Our position on the banks of the St. Mary River is a very prominent one, and a large Institution established there could not but be noticed by the travelling public. There are already

eight or ten large Institutions established in the States, the Carisle Institute in Pennsylvania—all Indian—with 600 pupils; the Lincoln Institute in Philadelphia, all Indian, with 200 pupils; the Institute in Virginia, owned folk and Indians, 600 pupils; the Salem Institute, Oregon, 150 pupils; the Haskell Institute, Kansas, 350 pupils; these and many others, and they are all of them either largely aided or wholly supported by Government. $167.00 per capita per annum is the usual allowance. Now it seems to us only reasonable that we should have at least some such institution established in Canada, and we propose to remodel and enlarge our present Institution, so as to take 300 pupils, and we shall ask the Government to give us at least $150 per capita towards the support. We rely on the sympathy and goodwill of all Protestant denominations in carrying out this work. eight or ten large Institutions established in the States, the Carlisle Institute in Pennsylvania—all Indian, without pupils; the Lincoln Institute in Philadelphia, all Indian, with 200 pupils; the Hampton Institute in Virginia, coloured folk and Indians, 600 pupils; the Salem Institute, Ohio, 150 pupils; the Haskell Institute, Kansas, 300 pupils, these, and many others, and they are all of them altogether under what is called the government system. OUR FOREST CHILDREN

TO THOSE WHO WILL INTEREST THEMSELVES IN THE WORK

We wish to inform the many friends who are interested in our work among Indian children, that we have arranged for this little paper, "Our Forest Children," to be issued regularly monthly; the size of the paper is a little enlarged, but the price will remain the same—10 cents. We also desire to call special attention to the Christmas number of Our Forest Children, which we propose to issue about Christmas time. It will be very prettily got up, extensively illustrated with original sketches engraved for the purpose, 16 pages in length, and the price 15 cents. For 25 cents we will send Our Forest Children to any address from the present time until December next, and the Christmas number now to be issued. We hope to get as many orders as possible for the Christmas number. In no other way can the friends of our Indian Homes help us just now than by sending $1 with the names and addresses of 4 new subscribers, to each of whom we will send the Christmas number of Our Forest Children and its contents.

Shingwauk Pupils to Montreal.

We are just back from a most interesting and successful trip to Montreal and Ottawa. What a business it was getting those 30 children ready! First, there was the selecting of which of them should go; then came the packing; the nicest-behaved must go; do not think that members of our church should be able to pack; of course we must not omit the two blackest draw from the school, and the two prettiest pack on that box. At length the 10 were decided on—20 boxes and another. We believe that our beloved mother church will gain infinitely more influence in this young country by owning her arms widely and acknowledging the need of work done by others than by attempting to do all herself. We must carry all that would be required for themselves during the 5 days' absence, and all the things required for the tableaux, and the large pictures to hang on the walls; and then when the packs were completed, all were weighed, and the weights regulated according to the size of each child. Then there were the provisions to see—to baskets for canned meats, biscuit, cheese, sugar, etc., tin cans for tea, water, milk, &c.; boxes packed tightly; large bags for bread and bags for apples for all the boys must have new hats, and these had to be trimmed with yellow and blue ribbons; and lastly there was the drilling and rehearsals for the tableaux and singing. Well, the day came at length, and they all looked very nicely as they started off at 6:30 in the morning—the boys all with their shiny black packs on their backs, the girls with satchels slung to their sides and all carrying flags in their hands. It was a loggy...
It was dreary and rain when we reached Montreal station at 8 o'clock Saturday morning. The Division fell in on the platform; was the first under cover, followed by the same order in the Second Division, and proceeded to the Victoria Rink. We marched in order up the centre aisle to seats set apart for them. In the afternoon we divided into three parties: David and nine pupils were to visit St. Luke's and Trinity Sunday Schools; Johnny and nine more were to visit the Roman Catholic Church. Mr. Macdonald and Mrs. Macdonald were to visit the Protestant Church. Mr. Macdonald was to take charge of the boys and Mrs. Macdonald of the girls. We were to meet again at the rink where the great Sunday School demonstration was to take place in the afternoon, and spend an hour getting things ready for the entertainment.

Owing to the wet weather the parade of 10,000 children belonging to the Protestant Sunday Schools through the streets of Montreal, had to be omitted—but the gathering in the Victoria Rink was a great success.
The Happy Little Indians.

The boys of the town had a glorious time of it last week, consorting with the children of the forest. Indeed all the families who threw open their houses to receive them were delighted subsequently at having done so. At the first they consented to the proposal with reluctance, saying, "It's with the woods," and they began to think whether a bed in the woods would not be more agreeable than the spirit of the roving rascals. But when the electric wires of human nature were strung, and the whites and reds looked into each other's eyes, the fog of misconception dissipated, and there came a feeling of warmth and fraternity. The "square" bed and the Benjamin's portion were freely bestowed. The children were exceedingly clean and neat. They ate with refinement of manner, were kind and good-natured, and with rather elaborate ceremonies, they commenced to perform kind and kind deeds made them laborious, and they made bows and arrows for the children in the houses they stayed, arrows and such things of mechanical cunning and that could shoot as straight as a line. One of the boys who stopped at Mr. Godden's asked one of the town group: "Shall I shoot down that bird in the tree?" Eagerly they fired off a volley of "Yeses." The bird was killed off-hand, picked up a stone, and in a flash the bird was tumbling on the ground. The two blackest youths stayed with Mrs. McKay. One of them had never been clothed except with a blanket until three months ago. There were some boxing matches in the house and Capt. McKay and one of his sons gave them exhibition, at which their faces lighted up merrily, and they looked on to the end with interest. Everywhere in the houses the children succeeded in imprinting indelible impressions; and when they walked out on the streets with polished boots and well brushed uniform, these impressions circulated into a wider area and were discussed with enthusiasm.

"OUR INDIAN HOMES"

ALGOMA, MANITOBA, and the NORTH-WEST.

This work originated in the year 1871, when the old Chief "Shingwauk" of Garden River (still living) accompanied Mr. Wilson to Toronto and other places, and addressed the white people, urging that a "Big Teaching Wigwam" might be built for the young Indians belonging to his tribe. The next year (1872), Chief Shingwauk went with Mr. Wilson to England, where he collected, and the first Shingwauk Home was built; this Home was destroyed by fire in 1873, six days after it was opened. The foundation stone of the New Shingwauk Home was laid by the Earl of Dufferin in 1874, and it was opened for use in 1875, by their Lordship the Bishop of Huron and the Bishop of Algoma.

This cut shows the present Shingwauk Home and its surroundings as completed December, 1886; also the sites of proposed new buildings. The explanation is as follows:

A.—The Shingwauk Home (stone), with accommodation for the fifteen boys (built 1874); B.—the stable (frame); C.—the chapel-built 1883 (stone); D.—the boys' hall (stone); E.—the boys' cottage (frame); F.—the form cottages (stone); G.—the boys' bath and wash-room (stone); H.—the furniture factory (frame).

The plan shows the proposed new buildings: I.—the central building; J.—the school rooms; K.—the dormitories; L.—the superintendent's quarters; M.—the proposed new Central Building; N.—the proposed new Laundry.

If these plans are carried out there will be accommodation for one hundred boys and fifty girls, and all will attend the one building for school and meals.

The Right Rev. the Bishop of Qu'Appelle, says of the proposed Home at Medicine Hat:

"I welcome most heartily and thankfully the independent Indians who are now preparing to commence. Medicine Hat is a place excellently suited for the work, being within reach of several large Indian reserves, having abundant water and coal supply. I trust you may have every success in raising the money."

At the present time, December, 1884, we have $1500 on hand, towards the Medicine Hat Home; and the people of Medicine Hat have promised subscriptions to the amount of $2500.

In order to secure a Government grant we ought to make a good start ourselves, and we trust that many of our friends will come liberally to our aid.

**MORE HELP NEEDED**

We earnestly pray that Almighty God will put it into the hearts of His people to aid us abundantly in carrying all these plans, for the benefit of the Indian Race, into effect. Our motto from the first has been—"A Work that is of God cannot be overthrown." Sunday Schools can very materially aid us by adopting an Indian child in one or other of our Institutions, and paying $3 (or if clothing is sent, $5) annually, towards its support. Four hundred and twelve pupils have been received at our Homes since they first commenced, and there are at present about one hundred and ten in residence.

**OUR FOREST CHILDREN.**

A Sixteen-page Illustrated Monthly Magazine, edited by Rev. E. F. Wilson. Price 15 cents per annum. Friends of our work among the Indian children, will very gladly aid us by subscribing. The expense of getting out nine or ten new cuts for each issue is very great, and the Magazine cannot pay its own way until we have about 2000 subscribers.

H. H. Halle, Clinton, Ont., says:—"A most agreeable and instructive monthly visitor, full of information, conveyed in a pleasant style and enlivened by sketches of personal adventure, very well told and attractively illustrated."

Dr. Francis Boas of Clark University, New York, says:—"The contents are highly interesting, and the terse description of Indian tribes and Indians is so full of value and significance, as they help to give the reader an adequate idea of the magnitude of the philanthropic work you have undertaken."

Particulars of Buildings in course of Construction at the Shingwauk Home

Extension (Place accompanying)

The New Buildings on the West side of the Home consist of a Kitchen, Boys Lavatory, and Bath Room on the ground floor, and a Reading Room and dormitory for 8 or 10 beds on the first floor. The present kitchen will in future be used as a Dining Room for the Employees and the new one will be more roomy and airy than the old one. The present bath Room leads out of the Dining Hall, a most inconvenient arrangement, in future the Bath Room and Lavatory will adjoin. The Well has been sunk, and has 6 feet of water in it. The walls will be half timbered to correspond with the Hospital and Industrial all our new Buildings, Stone Foundations.

The present Back Kitchen will be moved back 30 feet and brought in line with Main Buildings as shown on Block Plan. On the First Floor a Reading Room is provided with direct access from the school Room, also a Dormitory for 8 or 10 beds. Only last month we had to refuse applications for 6 children from Moravian town as we had not beds for them. The contracts are let and the buildings should be finished in about six weeks or two months - The estimated cost is $1,349 as per accompanying detached Estimate.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that owing to scarcity of funds we find it necessary to curtail our domestic work. We have judged it prudent to reduce the number of our pupils or staff at the Shingwauk and Wawanosh Homes during the winter months.

I am in the meantime representing to our Board of Domestic & Foreign Missions the necessity of these homes for Indian children which have been established at Sault Ste. Marie - at Elkhorn - at Medicine Hat - and placed on a more satisfactory basis, and require their support.

The result is that steps are now being taken to form an "Indian Auxiliary" in connection with the Board of Domestic & Foreign Missions, having its local committees at various points in Ontario, Manitoba & North West. These will be such as I am convinced will be more adequately supported & better supervised.

The Department will I think be pleased to cooperate.

TWENTY-FOUR years ago there was erected on the Canadian banks of the St. Clair River, on the Indian Reserve three miles below Sarnia, an unpainteted little frame school house; it was painted red, and the whole cost was only about $400. That was the beginning of our work among the Indians. Since then, by God's blessing, we have been enabled to erect as many as forty buildings at an aggregate cost of about $40,000. Four hundred and seventeen Indian children have entered or passed through our schools. Those who came first are now out in the world, mostly of their own race and settled with families of their own. Two of our pupils now at the Shingwauk are studying for the medical degree.

Many have heard of late who doubt the wisdom and necessity of expanding so much on the training of Indian children. They ask us, To what good is all? What becomes of our pupils after they leave here? Are they following the trades which we taught them? Are they doing well for themselves, among their own people? In reply we would say Yes; some of our pupils have become teachers—others are now making their living by the trades which they have learned here, as is already known by our Superintendent, Mr. John Indian Department, who is now studying at St. John's College, Winnipeg, preparing for the ministry. We do not pretend that any large proportion of our pupils have made an independent start for themselves. By far the largest number we know are still living on the farms, or in small way, working in the fields, or on the land, or as deck hands on steamboats.

This will probably not seem satisfactory to our friends, who believe it their duty to encourage, but we must see reason why there are so few of our converts. The difficulties are not entirely on our side, and we must content ourselves with saying that while we are doing our best, there is a great deal of prejudice against Indians, and the Indians are themselves often unwilling to work. We must also consider that when we started out, when offered these difficulties, we knew to a great extent what was in store for us. In the State of Pennsylvania, numbers of children who have been educated at the Carlisle Indian School are now out living on farms, working for the white farmers, and the Indians are hoping before long a similar state of things may exist here. Several of our Wawanosh girls are already out in service, and others are expecting to get places early in the new year.

Our work has been very active during the past year, and much increased during the year which has just closed. Our new Homes at Elkhorn have been opened. Improvements to property and additions to buildings have been made at the Shingwauk Home, and a site has been purchased in the far West for the establishment of a new Home in the Province of Alberta.

We cannot make too strong recommendations in connection with the work of the O.I.H., as it is being done by such hardworking people, who are willing to sacrifice everything for the cause of the Indians. We urge every one to read Our Indian Home, as it contains much that will interest and instruct.

THE SHINGWAUK HOME

The Government made us a grant of $2,500 last spring, and this, with other contributions, has been expended as follows:

We began by putting up a new comfortable little stone cottage for the accommodation of our newly engaged Missionary of factory and ox-packer, with his family. It was necessary to clear a number of men and teams were busy grading and levelling the wide stretch of land between the Institution and the new building. This was satisfactorily completed, sown with grass, and a handsome little band-stand erected. Here the base-ball matches are played, and musical visitors come to sit under the trees in summer and listen to our brass band. Then we...
making, and perhaps helped by harness-making. We also erected telegraph poles near the Shingwauk Hospital, Industrial and Factory are now all connected by telegraph. Besides being a convenience, it is also teaching the boys an employment which may some day be of use to them. The accompanying bird's-eye view of the Shingwauk shows at a glance what our improvements have been, and the sites also are marked for other important buildings, viz., the Building, where both boys and girls will go to school and have their meals in the "Industrial Home," and a new Laundry. It may take three or four years to complete all these buildings. When all are in operation we hope to have accommodation for about one hundred and fifty students.

Our Wawenak Home is at present sadly overcrowded. We have only beds for twenty-five girls, but have had to accommodate seven or eight more during the winter months. After Christmas two or three girls are going to be sent away, and thus the number will be reduced to suit the accommodations. Our happy thoughts about the Wawenak, especially interested in the fact that the girls' fingers are, with few exceptions, always busy employed. Each girl has learned to knit, and quite a lot of pairs of socks and mittens are very neatly knitted every week by the girls during their periods of leisure, each pair costing ten cents a pair. One girl does a great deal of knitting, and her work is excellent. She is also learning to sew, and is doing very well.

The Elk Horn Homes

The Homes at Elk Horn, near the Kawartha, for boys and the Wawenak Girls for girls, are now entirely completed and in full use. One hundred and forty acres of farm land also have been purchased some four miles from the Institution, and when the Spring opens, we hope, with Government assistance, to put up necessary buildings and commence farming operations. Mr. McKeever has proved himself a very efficient and painstaking Superintendent, and Mrs. and Miss Vala are doing all they
can to make the Elkhorn Homes a success; they have, however, difficulties to contend with from which we are comparatively free at the Shingwauk and Wawanoosh Homes, namely, the parents of the Indians who allow their children to run away, and many a time has there been a long and hard chase after runaways. The Indian children in the neighborhood of Elkhorn are many shades wilder than those which have been usually received at the Small St. Mary's Homes, and it seems almost impossible to impress upon

OF R. FINANCE.

Our finances at this present time are sufficiently low to cause us a little uneasiness. We had hoped to begin the year with a small balance; but no, taking into account the balance deficit last year and the unprofitable Government grant to put against it, and the balance deficit this year and the deficit this year, we find ourselves in a very bad position. Our expenses have increased greatly, and the general wants of the school have not increased proportionately. We must hope, however, for the best, and believe that He, who has helped us so far, will continue to work with us and send us the means and the proper friends to help us. No fear from giving in or closing down any part of our work, we are looking forward to still further extension this next summer. Already has the band of friends been enlarged by the addition of Mr. James Hat, government has been applied for a grant, and the answer so far is favorable.

Medicine Hat is an excellent location—supported by the Department, favored by the Bishop—and is in every contingency to meet the large Indian Reserve, on which it is located, the people of the town and the Indians.

We trust that our friends will now come to our aid and help us in the erection of this new institution at Medicine Hat—also that many new Sunday schools may be induced to take up our work and aid us by adopting and providing for an Indian child in one or other of our schools.

List of Pupils at the Shingwauk, Wawanoosh and Washakie Homes during the year 1889.

1. David Oakes was working at the Shingwauk till towards end of January, when he went to Ottawa to enter on his duties as clerk in the Indian Department.

2. Anna Johnson was sick during the latter part of the winter, and in May (1889) was sent to his home, where after lingering for some time he died.

He was an earnest Christian boy.

3. Edward Williams went to his home in October, and is yet coming back.

4. Peter Oakes was away all winter on account of sickness. He came back to us for a few months during the summer, but returned to his home in the fall.

5. Anna Scoltchin was very sickly last winter and spring, so we sent him home in the summer, and advised him to remain at home for a year.

6. Isaac Simpson did not return to us after the summer holidays. His father was very sick, and had to give up farming.

7. Peter Stone: Poor little Peter was very ill with a relapsing complaint all the winter, and was well nursed in the hospital by our good friend, Miss Pegler, who visited the Reformatory several times.

8. Peter Nezna: This is the naughty boy who tried to set the Shingwauk Home on fire Sept. 12th. He has been sent to the Reformatory.

9. Francis Baker was ill at his home with typhoid fever when school opened in 1889. August, so could not come back. We have not heard whether he recovered.

10. Charlie Baker did not come back after the holidays because his brother Francis was sick, and has not yet returned to school.

11. James Smith was sick a great part of the winter with pulmonary complaint, and when spring came we sent him to his home. We hear that he is somewhat better, and wants to come back to the Shingwauk.

Memorandum

To the Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,

The Rev. Mr. Wilson's letter of the 15th instant shows that, so far as he is aware, there is no threat from the Shingwauk or Nawaweshik homes at present. The precautions taken by guard against loss of life by fire are sufficient, but it is considered that means additional to those employed should be adopted to preserve the children should an outbreak occur.

Firstly, which seems to have fallen into disuse, is the curfew. There are two other dwellings in town, and that of summoning the boys by alarm to their beds at night and rising early they are taught to be neat and steady. Such a proper discipline can be relied on. The younger boys at Shingwauk and the girls at the Nawaweshik home should be taught to...
The corridors and stairs out of the building when an alarm of fire is given; this latter is a kind of drill to which much attention is paid in public schools in the United States, and proficiency in which has saved many lives.

The water supply seems to be very inadequate and measures should be taken by hydraulic ram or otherwise to force a constant supply of water into the building.

Smoking in the workrooms, barns and stables should be prohibited; lights should not be used in those buildings more than is absolutely necessary, and the lights should never be uncovered lights.

Additional barrels and fire pails as indicated on the plans should be placed in the corridors and fire stations, and fire extinguishers should be added to the other means of preservation from fire.

Report of Special Committee

St Regis, Que.
OTTAWA, 6th February, 1902

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant stating that Mary Semo, a pupil of the Wawanosh Home, has been ill for two weeks past and asking that you be put in communication with her father, Joseph Semo, a member of the St Regis Band, whom you have been unable to locate by letter; and in reply I beg to say that enquiries are being made as to where this man is at present living and when the Department is advised you will be notified at once.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Secretary

Geo. L. King, Esq.,
Principal,
Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (No. 10, Volume 0411, Issue 409-1, part 4)
Sir,

I have to inform you of the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant. We regret to inform you that Mr. John Wilson, Esq., of this place, has been informed by Mr. Smith, Esq., of this place, that he has been appointed to the office of Secretary of State for Canada West. Mr. Smith has also informed us that Mr. Wilson will be sworn in as Secretary of State for Canada West at the next session of Parliament.

We trust this information will be of interest to you.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

George Brown

[Stamp]
Indian Industrial School

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 15267, dated 13th inst., enclosing copy of Mr. Joseph Long's letter to the Department giving Joseph's name.

The girl, whom I have at present in my care, is recovering from her illness and is doing well. She is now able to walk and is improving daily.

I have this morning written to the Secretary of State for Canada, enclosing a copy of your letter.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have just heard from our pupil teacher Adams of the Department's kindness in providing him with an outfit of tools & finding him employment in Illinois, and desire to express my gratitude to the Department for its kind assistance to this boy.

I trust Mr. Adams will also show his appreciation, as I have urged him to do, by working steadily, and giving his employer any satisfaction and thus encourage the Department to assist other pupils in a similar way.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
